Tuned for 3D printing with no supports / designed specifically for 3D printing

title: Haribo 3030 X-axis with belt tensioner and cutouts for couplers

description.text:
This is the remix of the original x-axis from Prusa with additional belt tensioner. If you have Haribo and original Prusa motors (with integrated rod), it works fine, but when you have steppers and Z threaded rods connected using couplers, it's not possible to lower the Z axis enough to reach the bed. One solution is to raise the bed by couple of mm, my solution is to modify x-axis motor mount and idler with cutouts for couplers.

The original files were modified by extending the width of part by 2.5 mm, moving x-axis endstop and shorting bearing holders on x-axis to acomodate couplers. Max coupler diameter is 25mm.

The source files are available on Github

comments.author: danman24

description.text:
This is a work in Progress and the lure has NOT been tested yet!

This is just a prototype for an idea I'm playing around with using the new technique of printing on fabric. I did not come up with this idea I am just trying to find new creative ways of using it. I believe the original idea came from Shorey Designs from Instagram.

The design of the lure was just a rough 10 minute design I came up with to try this idea. I have no idea if it will actually swim correctly as I have not tested it yet. I am posting the file already because other expressed interest in trying it themselves.

The process starts by printing a few layers (two In this case) and then pausing the print. The tulle fabric was then taped to the bed over the print. The print was then resumed and continues to print over the fabric imbedding it into the print. The finshed print. The fabric acts as a hinge allowing the lure to bend. I add tie on/hook points and a little wieght (.177 BB's) and then superglue the two havles together. The finished lure before painting. Wiggle wiggle wiggle...... This video shows the entire process.

description.text:
56 x 49 x 15mm

36min print

Printer:

k8200

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Here is an idea I thought up a few years ago, and thought I would share it here for free.
It is a stacked vector concept that can be used to re-create almost any 3d model in any material that is in sheet form. I'm sure I'm not the first to think of this, but here it is anyhow.
By slicing a 3d model into slices the width of a chosen real world material, the profiles can be rendered out and cut out of that material and stacked on top of each other with dowels as locators.

I used the method to create this wooden airwolf model and a spaceship from the 80's TV series. See the V Spaceship here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2790202
I cut each slice by hand, which I don't recommend, but I supplied the files in DXF and Ai formats, so it can be cut with a cnc I beleive?
Since this method can be scaled using a projector, I have optimistic plans to create a full size Zuul terror dog from Ghostbusters by using this technique and large foam sheets.

I used a slice modifier in 3ds Max to do this, but I'm sure it's possible in most 3D programs
You can download the 3D printable models from these links:
https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/airwolf-3d-printable-model
https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/v-spaceship-replica

I hope this inspires!

I was annoyed with tracking hitpoints by placing stacks of counters near the board. It would get very busy fast and it was hard to keep track. So I designed this simple click-on hitpoint counter for minis with a 25mm round base. It goes up to 11 hitpoints but if you need more, you could just glue multiple on top of each other.

I was able to print the outside without a brim but results may vary. I suggest printing the inside in a lighter color to increase readability in tabletop conditions.

A complete redesign of RichRap's paste extruder.  This design will work on a RepRapPro Huxley.

See http://reprap.org/wiki/Mattroberts%27_Huxley_Paste_Extruder for detailed instructions on how to build. See http://richrap.blogspot.co.uk/2012/04/universal-paste-extruder-ceramic-food.html for hints on how to use. You probably want to use the replacement x-carriage ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27901 ) to allow for repeated switching of printheads. Assuming you use a 200 steps/rev motor: steps per mm will be 765. This number is calculated in OpenSCAD - so if you change the gear ratios it will calculate the new value for you.

title: 1" post adapter to 2" swivel caster (for commonly available wire shelf with 1" round uprights)

description.text: I wanted to put caster wheels on one of my shelves and didn't like the options I found locally for casters with a 1/4" threaded post (which would have been a lot easier). I designed these to adapt a 2" swivel caster to the 1" (25.6mm) legs of my shelf. For reference the casters I modeled for were Strongway 2" non-marking rubber swivel casters (with and without brake) purchased from Northern Tool. The screw holes in the adapter are 3.1mm which are a good pilot hole for a #8 x 1/2" wood or sheet metal screw. It is likely but certainly not guaranteed that a similar model caster from another manufacturers may work. The simple model is much more likely to work with a wider range of different models and is probably the better choice 90+% of the time.

Notes:

I'd recommend making the bottom 2-3 mm solid for the simple model or 4.5-5mm for the more complex model (I did 25 layers at 0.2mm resolution) to give the screws something to bite and a good solid base then 3-4 perimeter outlines for the rest. I used 30% infill but you shouldn't actually need any if you're printing enough perimeters.

The more complex model will need support for the 1.5 mm recess in the bottom unless you have very good bridging.

http://a360.co/2BmNB3u

http://a360.co/2H51SCr

http://a360.co/2H5B3Oo

author: ClintonRH

description.text:
Here is an idea I thought up a few years ago, and thought I would share it here for free.
It is a stacked vector concept that can be used to re-create almost any 3d model in any material that is in sheet form. I'm sure I'm not the first person to think of this, but here it is.

By slicing a 3d model into slices the width of a chosen real world material, the profiles can be rendered out and cut out of that material and stacked on top of each other.
I used the method to create this spaceship from the 80's TV series V, and a wooden airwolf model. See the Airwolf model here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2790179

I cut each slice by hand, which I don't recommend, but I supplied the files in DXF and Ai formats, so it can be cut with a cnc I beleive?
I used a slice modifier in 3ds Max to do this, but I'm sure it is possible in most 3D programs.
Since this method can be scaled using a projector, I have optimistic plans to create a full size Zuul terror dog from Ghostbusters by using this technique and large foam sheets.

You can download the 3D printable models from these links:
https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/airwolf-3d-printable-model
https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/v-spaceship-replica

I hope this inspires!
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Uf6S_i8x3hM" ></iframe>

I used two 4-40 machine screws that were 3/4-inch long initially (and corresponding nuts). I cut them to match the required dimensions for the handle. See images.

The inside of the handle has a pocket to accommodate the blade. You may want to heat the blade before clamping it, so that it melts into the handle ... especially if your handle is thicker than 1.2mm.

description.text:
The square and triangle blocks are both 50x15mm at the widest point

The square needs 12x 10x2mm magnets
The triangle needs 6x 10x2mm magnets

You need to glue the magnets in place CA glue works just fine. The holes for the magnets are 2.2mm deep so that the magnets don't stick out of the blocks to keep it all nice and even.

Yes they will melt if they are getting hot i just made them because i don't own tiny welding blocks and they can be really handy if you need them. Why buy them if you can make them? They are also a nice addon for 1-2-3 cnc blocks to hold them in place.

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

title: Valentine Heart Nut and Bolt turntable 180mm x 180mm

description.text:
Large Valentines Heart nut and bolt for your nerd partner.

The heart is 180mm x 180mm and 10mm high. It has a bolt embedded into it which fits with the nut in this thing. The nut has a 1mm larger thread than the bolt to make sure it spins nicely, and is 40mm high and 100mm wide to its edges.

The nut fits flush onto the bolt so it all lays flat.

I created a heart from Tinkercad and downloaded that as an STL and resized it. Then I used the Nut_Job.scad from Mike Mattala's excellent Nut Job:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Then I used the Net_Job.scad file in OpenScad on my PC and created the bolt and the nut.

This takes some time to print - on my Velleman K8200 the heart/bolt took nearly 11 hours, but it's a very satisfying print and fit. I'm not sure what you can use it for - it's just a nice large print for Valentine's Day,

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

I used 25% - your call with your printer/filament

author: colinhaynes

description.text: set fan 100% during the last part of the print

I used to mount flight controllers on the drone with double-sided tape with some foam in between but got sick of it because it can come loose and will not be perfectly level all the time.
To reduce vibrations, it usually helps to add more mass the the damped system, so this holder has place to also add the receiver, gps and telemetry if you like.
The GPS is mounted on top with some offset to reduce any interference with the flight controller using 20mm M3 nylon spacers. But you can also use the design without them, or with longer spacers.
You'll have to cut a hole for the arming switch and for USB-port access, but this totally depends on how you arrange everything.
You can use foam earbuds as dampener.

title: Lego Brick (Customizable), and tight snap-to fit

description.text:
I'd tried printing quite a few of the Lego bricks available out there but tended to find them a little loose fitting. azzeloof's openscad design was pretty good, allowing for full customization of the brick size, although, the bumps, or knobs on top still didn't quite make for a tight enough fit. All I've done is add a variable to the SCAD file to increase the knob size from 4.8 to 4.9mm (you can vary this as you please), the hard work was basically done by Adam Zeloof in 2013.

I've tested this on a Makergear M3 (not M2, as Thingiverse insists!) SE at 200 micron layer thickness, PLA, and it prints fine; the bricks snap together just as I remember as a child! Obviously you can print finer detail if required.

As always, your mileage may vary dependent on printer/filament etc.

author: INS4NE_ASSASSIN

title: AlieneilA's Anet A8 - Upgrades, Videos, Guides Lists
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A preview of my upgrades to my Anet A8 with links to all of the videos and articles that I followed to perform the upgrades, as well as to all of the parts I am using. Links to purchased parts are affiliate links. These are all parts I've actually purchased myself and am using, I'll gladly add photos of any part if in doubt. I feel I've spent enough time and money and am trying to help others with a list of resources that helped me. I am also putting the part name so you can search Amazon yourself without going through my links.

Update 3/2/2018

Added section for Titan Extruder assembly video, calibration video, my calibration settings for use with stock stepper motor, firmware settings, mount and photo.

Update 2/22/2018

  • Added information for the E3Dv6 Clone
  • Added section of upgrades not recommended to do towards the end.

Intro

A few weeks ago I purchased an Anet A8 for around $140 from Gearbest link. I learned as much as I could before receiving the 3D printer, but as I've learned in the few weeks since I received it... nothing is a good as first hand experience. While the things I learned before the 3D printer arrived helped a lot, I found that there was a lot I still didn't know. So I will try my best to post things I've learned, where I learned them and hopefully help someone else out that stumbles across this post.

Purchased Parts List and Cost including shipping

  • Anet A8 - 147.02
  • Titan Clone - 26.20
  • E3D v6 Clone - 15.98
  • Official BLTouch - 48.95 (included 1m cable extension)
  • Raspberry Pi Kit - 69.99
  • AM8 Frame - 54.42
  • AM8 Nuts & Bolts - 13.74
  • Rubber Feet - 3.20
  • Power Cord - 6.74
  • Power Switch - 2.44
  • Fuse - 0.08
  • Spool Bearings - 1.44
  • Idler Pulleys - 6.99
  • Mosfet - 8.99
  • GT2 Upgraded Belts - 8.99
  • Fans (2) - 13.96

Total cost of printer and upgrades:
$429.13

First thing's first... if you don't like DIY and don't like tinkering and testing and failing and experimenting... then the Anet A8 is probably not for you. It's a DIY project that takes a lot of patience and a lot of finagling to get things running better than stock. There's a lot of upgrades to make the printer better, and a lot of extra money you may need to spend. While the experience building and upgrading the Anet A8 has been fun for me, the amount of extra money I've put in to it, I probably just could have purchased a better printer that works better and is built better right out of the gate. But this has been a journey that I have enjoyed, even if it did make me want to rip my hair out a few times.

Starting Off

If you don't already have an Anet A8, I found the cheapest I could find one was through Gearbest. It did take about 2 weeks to receive it, but during that time I learned as much as possible about the printer and what I would need to do to make it better. A ton of YouTube videos were watched, and a ton of articles were read. To quote the baddest Demon Hunter... You Are Not Prepared!

Here are a few YouTube channels to start with:
  • Thomas Sanladerer: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCb8Rde3uRL1ohROUVg46h1A
  • 3D Maker Noob: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2Tc0TsvFxC83zF1w5x1PWQ
  • 3D Printing Professor: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJk5KVaJVBEEl_jP5gKjoDw
  • Maker's Muse: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxQbYGpbdrh-b2ND-AfIybg

There is a TON of information to be learned from those guys.

Initial Build

Now my experience has been a bit of a roller coaster. A couple times I almost threw in the towel and really thought to myself… WHY? Why did I buy a 3D printer? (to 3D print parts for my SteamPunk robot dragon) and Why am I willing to deal with all of this BS? I still don’t have an answer to the second question, but… I’m having fun lol.

Anet A8 Parts

The Anet A8 initially took me about 6 hours to assemble. Mainly because the nuts are a bit of a pain in the ass to keep in the little slots and not fall out. Aligning everything, running wires, connecting wires, redoing parts that I didn’t realize I put on backwards or upside down causing me to take half the thing apart to fix my mistake.

Some pretty good videos to help assembly:

  • Part 1: https://youtu.be/-tiHfzBQZpI
  • Part 2: https://youtu.be/EbNocv6-OOQ
  • Part 3: https://youtu.be/Ml1XGhJF4_E

Finally… it was together.

Anet A8 Assembled

After assembly, I had some problems. The left threaded Z axis was sticking pretty badly, and when moving the Z axis up and down it would continuously stick and get out of alignment. Having never dealt with this before, I was pretty frustrated. So I tweaked and tested and tore apart and ripped hair out and finally came to the conclusion that the threaded coupling was out of alignment. I took it apart and found a piece of plastic between the coupling and the part it was mounted to. After removing it and putting all back together, the Z axis movement was smooth as butter. Now I could print.

Just the stock printer really didn’t print too badly...

First Print

I probably could have stopped there and been happy printing things for personal use. But no… I’m a glutton for punishment.

Upgrades

Originally I had a list of parts I was going to print out to upgrade, as well as the parts needed to upgrade to a metal frame. Why? because the stock Anet A8 comes with an acryllic frame that isn’t very strong and can be wobbly. Anyways, that list changed over time and so I will post my upgrades that I’m actually using now.

Filament

You’re going to need some filament to print parts if you’re going for upgrades first, or even just to play around and start printing some things. I started off with 2 different filaments that were as cheap as I could find just to start off with and experiment with and waste…

  • 3D Mars Black PLA - https://goo.gl/sM5sGQ
  • Yoyi Green ABS - https://goo.gl/PAiqiY

Both of these filaments have actually been pretty good. Though with my new Printbite printing surface, I’ve had a hell of a time with the ABS getting it to stick and not warp. PLA and PETG has been just fine.

AM8 Frame & Safety Upgrades

My first priority was to upgrade the frame. I found what I think is a really great metal frame plan called the AM8. It’s more DIY and more money spent though. You can find the information, instructions and BOM here… https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2263216 In the file list there is information where to buy the metal frame parts as well as a list of nuts and bolts to order / obtain. You also need a couple other things such as rubber feet. While you’re ordering parts, you may as well get a power switch (the Anet A8 does not come with one), and a mosfet (regulate power to the hotbed without going directly through the motherboard)

  • BCP 12pcs Black Color Bumpers Pads Rubber Feet, 21x12mm: https://goo.gl/A1dDev
  • BIQU Heat Bed Power Module Expansion Hot Bed MOS Tube for 3D Printer: https://goo.gl/wMu5Aj
  • TOOGOO(R) AC 10A 250V IEC320 C14 Inlet Module Plug Neno Lamp Boat Switch: https://goo.gl/LvTSL6

  • BCP pack of 10 pcs F10AL Fast-Blow Fuse 10A 250V Glass Fuses 5 x 20 mm: https://goo.gl/aj8kDm

  • Mosfet wiring instructions: http://moderntoil.com/?p=850
  • Power switch mount with wiring instructions: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2000523 – this is a way to mount the power switch to the PSU. There is an image that I followed to wire the switch to the PSU.

With the AM8 I needed a clip to keep the switch mount against the PSU, so I created one:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2778692

I’ve also create a motherboard mount for the AM8 to hold the motherboard and 2 mosfets (some people also mosfet the power to the hotend) as well as an 80mm fan:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766440

I also had problems with the Y tensioner that the AM8 includes, so I changed it to this one:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2720717

Cooling & Belts

I purchased 2 fans, 1 to go on the PSU, held on with this part:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2353611

and one to go over the motherboard, fiberglass / rubber belt upgrades, and better idler pulleys

  • Cooler Master Sleeve Bearing 80mm Silent Fan for Computer Cases and CPU Coolers: https://goo.gl/3SMYQ4
  • 2 PCS x Aluminum Dual Ball Bearing Idler Timing Belt Pulley for 3D printers, 3mm Bore, 20 Teeth, for GT2 Belt: https://goo.gl/yKy4WU

  • RepRap Champion 5 Meter 6mm Width GT2 Timing Belt: https://goo.gl/sHTmc9

  • X belt tensioner: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1683070
  • X Belt Holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2016779
  • Y Belt Holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1997647
  • AM8 Filament mount holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469167

  • Spool Plugs with bearings: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2773587

  • Jeremywell 608-2RS Ball Bearing 8mm x 22mm x 7mm Rubber Sealed Deep Groove, Width Double Sealed (Pack of 10) : https://goo.gl/QcWvzh

After all of my parts arrived and were printed for the AM8 Upgrade… another few hours of taking apart the bed and putting things back together… note, picture shows the original mount I made for the dual mosfet and fan that was a mix of two other parts, you can find this one here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764658

AM8 Assembled

And the 4 final upgrades to this point…

Z Axis Sensor

I’ve added a BLTouch sensor (pain in the ass to add). I actually tried 3 different sensors, 2 were inductive sensors, a 4mm and 8mm sensing range. Both claimed to work simply by plugging in to the Z stopper, and I setup everything correctly… triple checked with articles and videos… and both of them crashed into my bed numerous times. The first one tore the hell out of my BuildTak printing surface and dug into my aluminum print bed.

BLTouch

BLTouch : Auto Bed Leveling Sensor (With 1M Extension Cable Set) : https://goo.gl/NbUotP

I have it mounted using this part https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2360242 which is also pretty cool because it allows you to just plop in your extruder fan to easily remove it and access your extruder gears. Instructions for Marlin Updates needed for BLTouch and how to zone it in correctly: https://youtu.be/G-TwWfUzXpc

How to wire the BLTouch to Anet A8 motherboard: https://youtu.be/6aofhlAooUE

Rasperry Pi and Octoprint

The Raspberry Pi kit I purchased pretty much has everything you need and then some. The board has built in wifi, it comes with a case, power cord, HDMI cable, 32 GB micro SD and a USB micro SD card reader to plug into your PC. There are extra USB slots to add a web cam as well (I am using an old Logitech webcam I used to use when I was a Twitch streamer)

CanaKit Raspberry Pi 3 Complete Starter Kit - Includes 32 GB Samsung EVO+: https://goo.gl/SYverN

And Octoprint allows you to connect to your printer remotely, control it, send prints, run console commands, etc. It’s been pretty awesome. Initially I used an old laptop and connected to it via Teamviewer, which also worked well.

Getting started with Octoprint and Raspberry Pi: https://youtu.be/MwsxO3ksxm4

Firmware

Firmware upgrade to the latest Marlin:
http://marlinfw.org

Anet A8 Marlin Firmware: https://youtu.be/2uX5_rI1QM8

Print Surface

Finally, Printbite printing surface:
https://flex3drive.com/printbite

Initially I used BuildTak. It came with an additional free one that I used first. My prints STUCK to BuildTak amazingly well… unfortunately, TOO well. While removing parts, pieces of the BuildTak ripped away with the part. I tore up the free one and placed the one I actually ordered… my first inductive sensor went rogue during a print, carved in a bunch of swirlies and then dug into my hotbed (see above). So I had to find something else, and since the BuildTak ripped apart when I removed parts, I found a bunch of positive reviews of Printbite so I got one. They didn’t have the specific bed size to order, but in the notes when I ordered it I told them my bed size and they cut it exactly to my dimensions, which was awesome of them. So far with PLA and PETG the parts I’ve printed have stuck GREAT, and when the bed cools the parts are SUPER EASY to remove. Some of the bigger parts even release themselves. It’s pretty awesome. With my ABS though, for some reason every part I’ve tried to print has released by layer 3 or 4. I’m thinking maybe my bed isn’t hot enough, as it didn’t have to be as hot with the BuildTak.

E3Dv6 Clone Hotend

My E3Dv6 Clone arrived, and while I haven't had any problems with the hotend itself, other things have been driving me nuts. I initially printed out an X-Carriage that had the LM8UU bearing holders as part of the carriage... that ended up being a big mistake because the alignment was off (distance between smooth rods was off by a couple mm or so) which caused my X-Axis to seize up and cause terrible prints. Then I had printed a hotend fan duct that the X-Carriage I'm using below linked to, and it was way too tall. I tried to print something without it on, and too much heat travelled up the hotend that it caused the clips to warp and make my extruder wobble... so I had to reprint the clip. I designed a hotend cooling fan duct to use, as well as a part cooling fan duct that curves around the back of the hot end instead of to the side or front so that I can still see my tip.

Purchased Parts

  • Wangdd22 E3D V6 Hot End Full Kit 1.75mm 12V Bowden/RepRap 3D Printer Extruder Parts Accessories 0.4mm Nozzle - http://amzn.to/2EPt32k
  • EAONE 2 Pcs PTFE Teflon Tube (2 Meters) with 4 Pcs PC4-M6 Fittings for 3D Printer 1.75mm Filament (2.0mm ID/4.0mm OD) - http://amzn.to/2GBXUjI (Mainly I just needed the fittings since the clone didn't come with any for the extruder side, extra tube is bonus for me)

Optional Purchased Parts

  • Extra Parts - Zomiee 5pcs Length Extruder 1.75mm Tube + 5pcs 0.4mm Brass Extruder Nozzle Print Heads M6 Threaded + 5pcs Aluminum Heater Block - http://amzn.to/2CDCeBp

Printed Parts

  • X-Carriage: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577
  • X-Belt Holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297824
  • Part Cooling Fan Duct - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2803449
  • Hotend Cooling Fan Duct - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2803512
  • BLTouch Clip - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2777969
  • Bowden Tube Clips - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936611
Titan Extruder Kit

I finally got my titan extruder kit clone, the one I used is from Gearbest and it took 2 1/2 weeks to get it. I used the stock stepper motor that came with the Anet A8 and calibrated it. Below are the parts I ordered, the mount I printed and the videos I used to assemble the kit and calibrate it.

  • Fully Kits for Bowden Direct Mounting Titan Extruder Bowden Direct Mounting 1.75/3.0mm for Bowden Extruder for 3D Printe - 424239.3MM BLACK: https://goo.gl/TerVoK
    (Note, this kit does NOT come with a motor, which is why I used the stock Anet A8 extruder motor)
  • AM8 Bowden Extuder Mount - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551526
  • Assembling the Titan Extruder - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QtEw-v0uL5s
  • Calibrating the extruder - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YUPfBJz3I6Y
    (Note, my default extruder steps per was set to 100 in Marlin. I had to change it to 429.16)

Additional firmware change: #define INVERT_E0_DIR false was changed to true.

Titan Extruder with stock motor Future Upgrades
  • Replacement bearings are ordered
  • Replacement X Axis Smooth rods are ordered
Conclusion

Someone asked me if all of the upgrades were worth it, and what my goal was... pointing out that for a bit more, a Prusa Mk2 wouldn't have needed the upgrades. So I'd like to add my response here...

To answer your first question, the goal of my post is to share information to others that may be going down the same path as I went through and hopefully make the process a little easier for them with the information I gathered. The goal of buying the printer and doing all of the upgrades was just to learn and gain experience with the 3D printing world.

Yes you are correct. For another $150 a Prusa MK2 is definitely a better buy in my opinion. And for a bit more the Mk3 is even better, especially with all of the new features, build plate, sensors and other upgrades that it has. When I initially purchased the printer, I didn't plan on all of the upgrades, but then once I got it and got onto thingiverse and watched a bunch of videos... the bug hit me. Had I known then what I know now, I would have just gotten the Prusa MK2 or splurged even a bit further for the MK3.

Has it been worth it? Maybe not all of the upgrades, I've even wasted more money on parts that didn't work... such as the 2 inductive sensors and the BuildTak. But... I HAVE seen improved printing quality, reduction of noise, safety, and after the new hotend and titan extruder get here, I can currently only assume that the quality will be even better according to those I have read opinions from.

On top of that, I've gained a lot of experience and learned a lot about 3D printers that I didn't know before. I've had to debug things and troubleshoot things that had a bought a more expensive printer, had something gone wrong... I wouldn't have known what to do about it. So there's value in that as well. IF I can figure out how to make a profit off of 3D printing, I'll purchase a better printer in the future. For now, I enjoy creating things, crafting, and tinkering with the printer.

Things I don't recommend doing: (so far)

Don't use Igus Drylin Polymer bearings - If they work, apparently they work great. Unfortunately, with an Anet A8 and printed parts being used, alignment is probably going to be even a hair off... which is bad news for these types of bearings. I have tried them, and to me they were a waste of money. Since I've switched to a bowden setup with an E3Dv6 clone, I am using a printed x carriage and I cannot get a perfect alignment which causes the X Axis to seize up frequently which makes the X axis to get out of synch with its actual position, so the layers shift... badly.

Don't use a printed X Carriage that has built in bearing holders. I tried 3 different ones before giving up and using a bowden X Carriage that allows for screwing on the bearing holders. The 3 I tried, none of them aligned right on the X Carriage and caused my X Axis to seize up frequently.

Don't use a cap that stabilizes the threaded Z axis rod. They float free for a reason. The Z axis already has smooth rods to keep the axis from wobbling. The threaded rods purposly are free on the high end to account for threaded rods that may not be perfectly straight. The Z motors connect to the threaded rods using couplings that move as the threaded rods sway. It's the smooth rods that keep your movement straight, the threaded rods just move the axis up and down. By capping the threaded rods and holding them in place, you are potentially introducing wobble to your prints.

Additional tools I’ve ordered just to make life easier
  • Pasow 50pcs Cable Ties Reusable Fastening Wire Organizer Cord Rope Holder 7 Inch (Black) - https://goo.gl/JQxJ5g
  • Zomiee 5pcs 30MM Length Extruder 1.75mm Tube + 5pcs 0.4mm Brass Extruder Nozzle Print Heads + 5pcs Aluminum Heater Block Extruder Kit for MK8 M6 Makerbot Reprap 3D Printers: https://goo.gl/Ma2GhL
  • eBoot Stainless Steel Ruler 12 Inch and 6 Inch Metal Rule Kit with Conversion Table: https://goo.gl/eJ6HxL
  • C2G/Cables to Go 03134 10ft 18 AWG Universal Power Cord: https://goo.gl/bd7QgG
  • Neiko 01407A Electronic Digital Caliper with Extra Large LCD Screen: https://goo.gl/cLrDRz
  • TEKTON Hex Key Wrench Set, Inch/Metric, 30-Piece: https://goo.gl/ZWofsU
  • Stanley STST17700 3-in-1 Tool Organizer: https://goo.gl/Ugomiq

title: Scangauge II Face and 4th gen 4runner mount

description.text:
My first Thingiverse submission, which is very much still a WIP.

This is a mount I am trying to make for my Scangauge II in my Toyota 4runner. It occupies one of the switch plates to the left of the steering wheel in LHD, 4th gen 4runners. The location it occupies is usually used by the Dash light dimmer switch, or seat position memory buttons.

To that end, I started with fmotta's Toyota Blank Dash Plate, which fits those switch positions perfectly. I cut off one corner somewhat sloppily, to allow the scangauge cable to pass though the hole at the same time.

I also cut a spacer from the modified dash plate's model, that can be adjusted to your preference.

I originally designed an arm that supported the scangauge from behind, but didnt really like the position. I decided instead of trying to modify angles of the mount, I would design a replacement faceplate for the scangauge. It's not perfect, but it does accept the original screws, and the button/RJ45 holes line up perfectly. I had a lot of difficulty getting the face to print a way that I like it. I may take a shot at abandoning the original screws and converting it to m3 hardware, which I think might let me simplify printing the mount as an assembly as well. My best attempt to print this part was face down, where the chamfers/fillets didnt do too well.

Files included:
cutmount.stl Modified Blank Dash Plate. Print with face vertically for best results. printing face down makes the prongs very fragile.

cutspacer.stl: Spacer to match the profile of the modified mount. adjust the height to your preference.

face3.stl: my current version of the Scangauge II replacement face. This is the first revision I could use where the screws didnt destroy the face. print at 100% infill, and fasten the screws slowly.

arm.stl: basic profile of the mount arm. attach it to the face, and you get the next file

facemount2: Arm and face attached.

longer pins.stl: Pins to fasten the mount, spacer, and arm together. you may have to adjust their length if you've made the spacer thicker.

mountallenconversionv3 is a face/mount with a set of pins that works with the original switch plate but integrates a 5mm spacer, uses m3 hardware to secure everything including the faceplate, and several rounded edges. This is likely not the last revision, but is the first one I'm really satisfied with. If you make one, just be careful not to overtighten the screws you use for the faceplate

If you find success with any of these models please let me know, or if you have suggestions for improving its quality.

title: Cube Spinner: Two Versions (Loose or Grooved)

description.text:
Cube Spinner: Two Versions (Loose or Grooved)

If we make a circular cut around a vertex of a cube, we get a spinner after adding a bit of tolerance. The structure has a strong aesthetic appeal. My first experiment was given to a little kid in my math class, who said he likes it so much and he wanted to keep it. Of course, I said yes, with the parent’s approval.

To keep the core from coming out, we can add a groove. So I tried it, based on my previous work on spinning structures. It turns out to be a great math toy!

There are two versions here (with two sizes), both of which can be printed in one piece at a resolution 0.1mm. The loose one allows the core to come out so one can see its inner structure. It is easy to separate. The grooved one calls for a bit of wiggling but still works well according to my experiments. Be patient! Loosen the two pieces, clean up the edges as necessary, and turn it around for a few minutes for smoother rotations. A drop of lubricant may also help. Have fun!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

Notes:

Please use a high resolution for the grooved version (0.1mm). Please do not scale them down because of the tolerance.
Wiggle a little bit, loosen the two pieces. Clean up the edges as necessary and turn it around for a few minutes for smoother rotations. A drop of lubricant may also help.

description.text:
I designed this spool roller to be silent in operation, have low rolling resistance, and low bearing revolutions for increased bearing longevity.

This should work for nearly any size or weight filament spool.

It requires:
6 x 6088ZZ bearings.
1 x 6.5" OD (165mm, 2.5mm) O-ring (optional but recommended)

To assemble, think "3, 4, 5". The 3 spoke part is the base, the 4 spoke cruciform is next, add the spacer, and finally the 5 spoke top.

The rubber o-ring is nice because it provides a uniform but non-skid contact with the table or 3d printer. Rubber feet would have made the bearing track bumpy.

Please post your comments and makes!

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed everything at 100%. I wanted the center pins to be extra strong. I also wanted the spool wedge to be heavy. The spool wedge self centers the spool if you just drop it down on the spindle. Works great!

This is an updated file. I redesigned it and incorporated "nubs" to secure the bearings better. I also better matched the dimensions for the Prusa bed support . These can be secured with nuts and bolts or the U bolts although the bearings will not breakfree once pressed into the bracket. I used PETG for the filament.

I have now swapped out all the bearings on my Prusa mk2S for the ones made by IGUS with great success. Much quieter. These brackets I made for the bed.
I designed these on Fusion 360.

description.text:
Note:
Use V2 versions of the base and rod if you want a more forgiving fit.
If you have an M10 grub screw, that can also be used to connect the rose to the stem - only if you can't get the printer to print screw threads properly.

Note that this prints with monoprice select mini - but use 0.175mm magic number for layer height instead of 0.2mm.

I don't like gluing parts and prefer to connect them with screws and threads. Preferably with threads I can print.

I took the SuperRose design, simplified the geometry a litte in Fusion 360, added some M10 threads and a grub screw and it appears to work.

Only the grub screw might need a brim for surface adhesion, all other pieces should print without any need for raft or brim.

There are two versions of the stem. One that can print in one piece and a second version that splits it into two pieces suitable for smaller printers.

title: iPhone 6/7 Plus VW Car CD Tray Mount [REMIX]

description.text:
This design is a combination of remixes of other CD tray smartphone holders. After some trial and error and printing some designs I found here, I remixed the ones that seem to work best for me.

This tray holder was designed around the VW Monsoon stereo system and has been customized for its CD tray slot. This should fit into any VW GTI, Golf, Jetta and EOS with a Mosnoon radio. Should also work with Seat and Skoda models that use the same car stereo. I use this with my iPhone 7 Plus (with no case). If you have a very thin case it might be a snug fit.

The fit is snug to the CD tray so your phone or cd tray holder should not bounce around during acceleration and deceleration. This was another issue I had with other similar designs I printed.

Pro tip: In my trial and error phase I realized not all CD tray slots have the same dimensions so measure yours before you print ;)

Based of dlsifree's design/remix I needed a CD tray holder to mount my iPhone 7 Plus. I replaced the tongue design with teke28's CD https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2360563

title: Modular Bird Feeder Perch for Gazorpa’s Soda Bottle Feeder Base

description.text:
I remixed Gazorpa's Soda Bottle Bird Feeder with this modular perch that would extend the diameter of the feeder to approximately 180mm. Tolerance is pretty tight so I suggest scaling a little larger, I used 102% and I dipped it in hot water before sliding it over the rim of the feeder base and quickly squeezing the outer and inner tabs together while the plastic cools. It should fit pretty snugly once it cools and hardens. Glue was not needed but a tiny drop should be enough to keep it securely in place

Print as many as you want (12 would cover the entire base and give you a full circle). I suggest 3-6 to save on plastic.

Support not needed but I suggest a zero offset skirt/brim and 3-4 outlines to make sure the inner tab stays in place during the print. I printed this with 20% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom, and 3 perimeters. I was able to fit 3 onto my Monoprice Select Mini to save some time.

title: BFight210 Top Plate with Shark Fin with Realacc AXII Antenna Holder

description.text:
This is a top plate with a shark fin and a Realacc AXII antenna holder for the BFight210 frame.

BFight210 Frame: https://www.banggood.com/Bfight210-210mm-Carbon-Fiber-FPV-Racing-X-Frame-4mm-Frame-Arm-p-1181906.html?p=6Z050013977120130325&utm_campaign=139771_1210911&utm_content=1081

My original was just a top plate and thinner shark fin. It broke pretty easily especially when printed out of PLA and flown in cold weather. This one has a shorter fin and with the AXII holder in place, it should give the fin some extra strength. If it is printed out of TPU, it will not give as much support as a "top plate", but the fin would probably survive more crashes.

I added some material to come down around the spacers because that is where I was having issues with it breaking in crashes. This seems to have made it much sturdier.

BFight210 Frame Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPsZDmpBWAE
BFight210 Ultra-Light Parts Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NOXrvOpuOd4

title: Elevation model from a part of São Paulo

description.text:
X/Y scale is 1:50000, Z scale is 1:10000 to make it easier to visualize the terrain.
I made this using a QGIS shapefile and Rhino. I used the patch command, so there is some deviation from what you'll get if you triangulate the points, but then again, there will also be a deviation between a triangulated model and the real world so in the end it doesn't matter that much. It would be nice to use the same method to generate a larger model to be made in a CNC router, but since my CNC router isn't finished yet, this works quite well as a proof of concept.

I believe models like this would be great for a topography class.

Printed in ABS with a 0.8mm nozzle, 0.4mm layer, forgot to turn on retraction.

Notes:

Print the file oneplusone-nologo-hole.stl. The other STL file is freewilly's original that lacks a microphone hole.

Print vertically on a raft. Use 0.8 mm shells and no infill — any infill may make the surface rough.

Total printed size: 88 x 21 x 158 mm

Clean up camera and mic holes with a sharp knife. Make sure that the sides of the print are free from lumps inside, as the phone won't fit the case well if there's anything in the way.

You will need to flex the case slightly to get the phone inside. Some PLA filaments are very brittle and may not work. I used PLA+ which is very slightly flexible.

For a smoother and slightly more durable finish, paint the outside back and sides with a couple of coats of acrylic medium. Don't use any on the inside as it will interfere with the phone fit.

title: General use 3d printer compatible nut and bolt

description.text:
I was looking for a nut and bolt combo to print with which to secure down some stuff, but most if not all of the nuts and bolts i found were modeled after some standardized steel nuts or something. While this might sound all fine and dandy it's not really ideal if your printer has trouble with overhangs, and mine has, so i decided to make this from the tinkercads customizable ISO metric thread, playing with it until i managed to make it so that there are no overhangs over 45 degrees in angle. I meant this to be hand designed but either a 12mm or 20mm wrench ought to work for the bolt and a bit bigger ones for the bolt that is scaled to 110%

The thread diameter is 10mm, make it smaller or larger by scaling in your slicer.

edit: whoops, remember kids, only scale your nuts in the x and y for clearance and not in the z if you do not want damaged bolts

title: Replacement button for Tivoli Audio One

description.text:
The wonderful Tivoli Audio Radio Model One has a weak on-off-switch, which tends to break after some years. Since already two buttons in my family broke, and spare parts are not available, I decided to design a functional replacement and print it 3D (FFF).

The axle is 6 mm in diameter, and the button hole has also 6 mm diameter. Maybe that it fits a bit too tight. In this case, you can either scrab a bit out with a small knife, or you just enlarge the object to 102% in your slicer program.

The two knobs I printed do not look 100% as the original, but they work perfectly. For this small object, you can print with 0.1 resolution and slow speed (~40 mm/s) to obtain a very fine surface quality. I printed the buttons with the cheap Malyan M200, also known as Monoprice Select Mini.

Printer:

Malyan M200 = Monoprice Select Mini

After designing the first "tab" style, the fingers inside my push fitting completely broke off. After unsuccessfully trying to source some new fittings locally, I read on a forum that someone used a nut and threaded it onto the outside of the PTFE tube and then tied it to the extruder.

I used a #10-24 nut and it threaded nicely onto the outside of the 4mm PTFE tube and taped it onto the fitting while I printed this new bracket. I found that my prints actually turned out better after installing this bracket as the bowden tube no longer moved up and down.

description.text:
This is a miniature ruined building for 28mm/Heroic scale skirmish wargaming, such as 9th Age Skrimish Campaigns, Mordheim or, I suppose, Frostgrave. It's »gothic« in the same sense Wood's painting is - the windows are pointed arches.

This was a mastodon project for me - I feared I'd run out of time and lust before the design was completed (it shows, the latter features, such as the stairs, are rather simple) but I managed it. Printing, assembling and painting it took some effort too ...

I'm not overtly happy about the design, there's a few things that should have been made differently, but I'm very pleased I came to something and I learned a lot. Let me know if you'll try and print one of your own. I might be able to offer some additional help with this rather complicated print.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

You'll need one of each stl file, except the buttress A and pillar A, both of which you'll need 3 of.

I recommend printing the pillars and buttresses one at a time and with high resolution (0.1 or 0.12 mm). They're the most detailed pieces and will look their best this way.

The other pieces are large, so you'll want to spare time and print them at 0.2.

The largest piece, floor A, is approx. 185 mm at its widest, so you'll need a print surface to boot.

Assembly is a bit complicated. You'll need 1mm steel wire and good glue (I use a combination of Superglue and common wood glue) and/or a soldering iron. Parts might need to be filed to fit.

Start with the lower floor, fixing the two wall parts with a wire and gluing the stairs into place in the corner.

The floor pieces fit together with to pieces of wire (and some glue). Unfortunately, they'll just have to be glued onto the lower floor walls.

The upper walls, the floor and the pillars go together with wire. Finally, the buttresses can be glued on.

Automatic fish feeder remixed from coberdas and UrbanAtWork. I designed everything in Fusion360. You can access the design here: (http://a360.co/2BmqVjW). It is designed around a Nema17 stepper motor. I used this one (https://www.automationtechnologiesinc.com/products-page/nema-17/nema17-stepper-motor-2/).

IMPORTANT!!! The lid and standoffs may load into your slicer in a vertical position. They print better rotated into a horizontal position which I would recommend. The hopper may load laying on its side. Rotate it so that the small end is at the bottom. Some of the parts purposely fit snug. Wiggle them around or rotate them in the case of the auger to loosen them up a bit.

Motor attaches with M3 35mm socket head cap screws (mcmaster part#91292A033)
Motor shaft attaches to auger with an M3 set screw (McMaster part# 92605A100) but any M3 screw will work as long as it doesn't extend out to the spacers. There is a slot in the motor shaft end of the auger that you can slip an M3 hex nut (McMaster part# 90710A030) into.

Designed in FreeCAD

Salt Pepper Spice Shaker

Who doesn't need a lever operated salt, pepper and spice shaker :-)
Okay, I admit this is a little over the top. Still it was a fun little design project.

We have some large salt and pepper shakers from that well know food container company that begins with a "T". They have nice hinged lids but even though they are new, the lids fall off all the time. So I started out just wanting a design that captured the lid better. The lever and "odd ball" lid design were just for fun. The ball of course doesn't provide an air-tight seal, but it will help keep out dust and bugs.

My other goal was to design the parts so they could all be printed without any support.

The salt and pepper versions are obvious. The spice shaker has a large opening so it can be used for things such as crushed pepper, cocoa, cinnamon, or whatever you like.

Printing Instructions

As mentioned above, if you print with PLA with the files as they are presented, there is no need to add any support. They should print out perfectly. I made the fit slightly loose so that there is nothing critical. The layer thickness and infill also isn't critical. I used 20% infill. Even though PLA tends to be rather brittle, the spring on the lever worked fine with both PLA and PLA+. For other materials you will need to test if support is needed.

title: Oxo Palm Brush Draining Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed this little sink accessory to hopefully address the mess that our Oxo Palm brush kept making with water everywhere on the countertop. It's key features are:

  • Water is channeled down down and out the front
  • Printed in PETG to hopefully be top-rack dishwasher safe
  • Two pieces for easier cleaning
  • Bottom of the dish is channeled in order to reduce water pooling underneath

I'd made several versions before, in Tinkercad before starting on this one a few months ago as a learning project for Fusion 360.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Dish 0.10mm / Grate 0.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Grate:
Print the grate at whatever layer height you want (I used 0.20mm), with maximum perimeter walls. The grate prints well with multiple perimeter walls instead of gap fill, in order to reduce the area that water can collect in all those lilttle 3d printing gaps.

Dish:
It's important to print the dish at a fine layer height (I used 0.10mm) in order to facilitate the flow of water down the center channel without pooling on each layer step. In addition, I printed with 3 perimeter walls, 6 top layers and 4 bottom layers in order to eliminate water seeping through into the spare infill.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion360

title: Subnautica Cuddlefish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update:
I've made a new version of each body, which supports 7mm googly eyes.

I exported the model for the Cuddlefish from Subnautica, and modified it to use the modular ball-joint arms (from 3DCentralVA and Ellindsey).
Though the arms have been modified in size to give them a slight taper.

There are two versions of the body.
The normal one is closer to the raw game model, in the sense that the mouth is more open, showing a few tiny teeth.
The other one ("ClosedMouth") is where I closed the mouth so that I wouldn't have to remove supports in that narrow area :)

To print the complete model:

1x Body
2x Top arm
2x Bottom arm
1x Middle arm

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2>0.05

Infill:

10% 3D Honeycomb

Notes:

Printed with 3DE Silky Gold PLA

I first tried printing the whole body in one go with rafts and supports, but that din't end well. The supports didn't work properly and the socket joints fell apart.
And when I tried to plug in the tentacles/arms into the other sockets, they cracked instantly since there where horisontal layers.

So the final version I printed was when splitting the body in two, and simply gluing the two halves together.

And more importantly: I heated up the socket joints slightly with a heat gun before plugging the tentacles/arms into it. So that they wouldn't crack.

title: Aven 17010 Adjustable Circuit Board Holder Bushing

description.text:
The Aven 17010 Adjustable Circuit Board Holder available on Amazon has a design flaw that keeps a good product from being great. The spring used to compress the PC board digs into the plastic upright causing it to chip away at the plastic and, if you spin your PCB the wrong way, causes the PCB to rotate in the opposite direction you were trying to spin it. This is very frustrating because soldering is already a 3 handed job.

The bushing is installed between the spring and the plastic upright. You will need to remove and reinstall the "C" clip to install the bushing. The bushing significantly compresses the spring, limiting the amount that it can be compressed after the bushing is installed but there is still enough room to compress the spring to remove/insert the PCB without having to adjust the position of the upright.

Inserting the metal shaft into the bushing is a tight fit but I did not want a sloppy fit that could cause the PCB to wobble while you are trying to solder a joint.

author: SuperSteve

title: Taranis QX7 Gimbal restrictor plate for M7

description.text:
Maybe I have short fingers....maybe my hands are too stiff....I don't know. However, the gimbals on my Taranis QX7 always felt as if they have too much travel distance to reach the stops. I always compensated with my rates.

FrSky wisely made the M9-R gimbal for the Taranis X9D radio https://www.frsky-rc.com/frsky-hall-sensor-gimbal-for-racing-pilots-m9-r/ . Billed as the "Racers" gimbal, it shortens the stick throw by 25%. However, FrSky decided to forget about us QX7 users, as they don't make a "Type-R" gimbal for us.

Enter the Restrictor Plate for QX7. These plates simply snap into the silver rings surrounding your M7 gimbals and reduce the travel by ~25%, mimicking the M9-R travel distance.

No permanent modifications or disassembly of radio are necessary. They simply snap into place, and can be removed with little effort if you don't like them.

After they are installed and centered correctly around your gimbal(s), you will have to perform the gimbal calibration from within the radio's settings. There are videos on Youtube showing how to do this, and it only takes a few seconds. The calibration sets the new end-points of the sticks and retains the full 1000-2000 data points of resolution. The reduced travel distance combined with the full 1000-2000 points of resolution makes your M7 gimbals even more precise with less finger/hand movement. If you later change the stick ends to something other then the stock "lotus" style (or remove the restrictor plates), you will have to perform the calibration again.

These restrictor plates work with FrSky QX7 M7 gimbals ONLY.

I printed in black PLA to match my radio.

author: alexhome

description.text:
Varita de Hermione Granger.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbZxbHDOeCo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hzX8REbpUeo

Viendo algunos diseños en esta página de varitas, vi que las que había de Hermione no me acababan de convencer aunque estén muy bien conseguidas.

Una vez acabada, las características son:

· Led RGB: en este caso se usarán los colores rojo, verde, azul y "blanco".

.Microcontrolador ATTINY85: será quién realice todo el procesado de los datos. Su modo de sueño permite "dormir" a la varita si ésta no se ha movido durante un tiempo, muy útil para el ahorro de energía. Es posible sacarlo del modo sleep mediante interrupciones externas y además dispone de interrupciones internas. Todo esto unido a que se puede programar con Arduino y que no son necesarios muchos pines pero sí espacio reducido hacen de este microcontrolador la opción perfecta.

.Pilas LR41: conectadas en serie para proveer un voltaje de 3 V.

.Sensor de inclinación: capaz de detectar si está de pie o inclinado, será la entrada del micro y quién detectará cuando movemos la varita.

Más información de cómo funciona y cómo la hice aquí un pequeño tutorial:
https://eltallerdekvothe.blogspot.com.es/2018/03/varita-de-hermione-rgb-con-sensor-de.html

Si te gustó, agradezco los likes :D

title: GoPro Servo Mount Tilt Gimbal Drone/Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is designed to fit a Standard GoPro, although I am actually using a cheap action camera in it at the moment.

I made this mount to hang under my Diy Quadcopter. To serve as a tilt gimbal and anti vibration mount. To finish it you will need a 9G Micro Servo and a 4x7x2.5 bearing, the screws that come with the Servo are what fix it all together. Then to connect the top plate to the main hanger you will need "DJI" anti vibration rubber mounts with anti drop pins. The top plate is fits with M3 bolts which are spaced 10mm apart

It means you can have a tilt gimbal for about £6 if parts are ordered from ebay (links Below) adding your own printing cost.

https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Rubber-Damping-Ball-Anti-Drop-Pin-Kit-Set-For-DJI-Phantom-3-2-Gimbal-Cam-UKYQ/273053300825?hash=item3f933eb859:g:27IAAOSwjodZ8Fgz

https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/1-10x-SG90-9G-Micro-Gear-Servo-Motor-Remote-Control-RC-Robot-Helicopter-Airplane/282696826700?hash=item41d20b3f4c:m:mFBbmYPVpFl482C8eqX3E_w

https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/MR74ZZ-4X7X2-5-Miniature-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearing-Double-Shielded-ID-4mm/322865361959?hash=item4b2c467427:m:mxaAADQWF6Kr0v7WbwxPb5w

Printer:

TRONXY P802MA

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

I used 0.2mm layer height.
I printed this at 200 degrees in PLA. For the GoPro part I used supports for the ends, more so just to ensure the accuracy as they have to fit pretty snug in the bearing and on the servo mount. You may also want to try using a raft (I didnt) to reduce warping but it didn't affect the end fit of the camera.

First attach the cage to the hanger; first push the servo into place and fix with one of the included screws, on the other end push the bearing into the hole on the hanger, then push the cage pin into the bearing. Flexing the hanger push the servo pin into the other end of the cage then fix with the screw from the inside.
After that attach the Hanger Plate to that assembly with the rubber mounts and secure with the non-drop pins, this then leaves the top of the mount flush for fitting to the quadcopter frame.

The fit of the Ends to the hardware is very close, on the bearing side you may need to shave/sand it slightly to get a fit that isnt too tight. On the servo hole I used a bit of superglue to ensure it doesn't split and slip

title: Hexalenses - Hexagonal Articulated LEDs Of Arbitrary Shape/Size

description.text:
Created mostly as a byproduct of teaching myself new tools in Fusion360.

I use the little ws2811 12mm pixels for these:
https://smile.amazon.com/Diffused-Digital-Pixels-Lights-Addressable/dp/B00B4UKG2W?sa-no-redirect=1 - mine fit perfectly, but you might print one to verify fit with your printer before printing a big batch of these.

They assemble with zipties at the midpoint of each side and can be used to create a relatively sturdy mesh. I'm just using some small clear zipties I had laying around.(1mmx2.5mmx100mm) but I could have gotten away with much shorter ones. I trimmed a lot of ziptie plastic into the trash.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20

Notes:

Careful about going too low on infill. One of my earlier attempts at 10% was far too weak on the ziptie mounts. If I had a slicer that supported different infill by area, I'd probably do 5-10% inside the lens and 50-60% in the ziptie mounts, but alas- I settled on 20% personally.

Also, I had some trouble getting them off the bed at first. Spritzing the bed with isopropyl helped a lot. Anytime there's a large flat area like this and you want to protect it, isopropyl is your friend.

Not much to say, I printed these, picked them up, and started using them.

I did want to congratulate my Prusa on printing 19 of the 20 despite one of the middle objects failing shortly after starting the print. I woke up to find it almost done and not really caring that one of the objects had come free from the bed and was making a mess of itself. Never seen a bed full of parts work fine after a failure on one of them, especially not that early in a print.

There's no good reason you couldn't make these tesselate in some other shape or size. 19 makes a regular hexagon about 20cm (8") across.

Code

The easy version of the code is up here:
https://github.com/bobiam/hexalenses_nanonly/blob/master/hexalenses_nanonly.ino

It's super simple. You just connect a 5V source to your nano and your lights (don't forget to tie the grounds together) and connect the light data pin to digital 3. No further circuitry needed. You might need to tweak the color order of your LEDs at the top of the arduino sketch. I started from the center pixel as [0] on the strand and spiraled out from there, which matters to your sketch if you run my code (it determines where the various sub-hexagons are through a manual map). If you don't have any patterns that clearly demonstrate hexagonal shapes, check the hurriedly sketched diagram of LED mapping doom.

This sketch also uses the reset button on the arduino to advance the pattern.

I have some more complex stuff going on in:
https://github.com/bobiam/hexalenses/blob/master/hexalenses.ino - but it'll require 4 buttons wired into your circuit and it's a little more frustrating to work with.

Fusion 360 - I was mostly just poking around in some tutorials and made this.

http://a360.co/2sqxDm0

Here's the model if you want to poke at it. I'm really just learning Fusion360, so tips are super appreciated in the comments if you see something I've done that's way out of whack/could have been easier some other way/etc. Seriously, feel free to even say "Hey, you should look into fritzlflinging" or whatever if there's a Fusion360 way of doing something I'm missing out on. I'm happy to go watch more tutorial videos. There's just so much in this app that I'm sometimes overwhelmed trying to figure out what to learn next.

This is fully functional pipette capable of measuring volumes between 5µL and 20µL with comparable precision to a standard P20 pipette. The design is based off of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:255519 and uses cuts of latex gloves to form a membrane-based air displacement type micropipette. This pipette is able to measure smaller volumes with higher precision due to a lever mechanism that reduces button presses of a centimeter or so down to a few millimeters at the membrane interface. I have provided data as to how many turns of the button translates to changes in measured volume but this will need to be calibrated for each printed pipette so the accuracy may not be guaranteed. This project was actually completed back in 2014 and I'm not entirely sure why I never uploaded it. Possibly, the assembly guides were getting a bit complicated to make. Below are some assembly tips which should help but are by no means a complete guide.

Assembly Tips:
You will need a few cheap pens, mainly just the springs and ink cartridges.

First you will need a pen ink cartridge and spring cut to fit inside the head case. This assembly should be the same as for the Biropette (assembly steps 2/5) https://cdn.thingiverse.com/assets/ed/92/35/cc/e0/Pipette_v15.pdf
Use a leftover piece of pen and glue to hold the lever in place. When finished, the lever should press the pen cartridge down enough to barely press on the membrane on the pipette head.

The button assembly is going to be the trickiest part so I'll try to explain it the best I can here. Body parts A and B should interlock and fit pretty solidly around the head case but do not tape it down yet. Cut one of the ink cartridges so that it will fit between the small limiter screw and barely fit through the hole in the button limiter. You can glue this segment to the small limiter screw and fit one or two pen springs over it. Feed the pen through the lever and the button limiter and adjust the limiter screw as necessary until the assembly allows you to press the button limiter and spring back. The volume you measure will be determined by how much you screw in the button since this will hit the pen you just inserted.

Videos of how it works:
https://youtu.be/oY5QMazP4l4
https://youtu.be/wxp85X_9v54
https://youtu.be/sPJaCBCXeoI

Videos of assembly guides:
https://youtu.be/_P9So7ywgTk
https://youtu.be/DnkBVM0cAXI

I recognize the assembly guides are far from complete but if there is enough interest in this thing I may update it to be more in-depth. Questions and critical feedback are welcome.

title: Glaucus atlanticus - Model - Pendant 3D - Blue Angel

description.text:
Glaucus atlanticus (common names include the sea swallow, blue angel, blue glaucus, blue dragon, blue sea slug and blue ocean slug) is a species of small, blue sea slug, a pelagic aeolid nudibranch, a shell-less gastropod mollusk in the family Glaucidae.

These sea slugs are pelagic: they float upside down by using the surface tension of the water to stay up, where they are carried along by the winds and ocean currents. Glaucus atlanticus is camouflaged: the blue side of their body faces upwards, blending in with the blue of the water. The silver/grey side of the sea slugs faces downwards, blending in with the silvery surface of the sea.

Glaucus atlanticus feeds on other pelagic creatures, including the venomous siphonophore, the Portuguese man o' war. This sea slug stores stinging nematocysts from the cnidarian within its own tissues as defense against predation. Humans handling the slug may receive a very painful and potentially dangerous sting.

Assembly

Fix the mount to either upper left corner of your iMac depending on your preference. Use double-sided adhesive tape or a mild alcohol-based glue (e.g. rubber cement) to avoid damaging the anodized finish of the iMac's aluminium case. Dutch Windmill



This Dutch windmill has been designed in such a way that it can be 3D printed on an FDM 3D printer without the use of support material. Only the 6 RAILING parts need a small support pillar on one of the ends.

The BLADE parts can be printed flat and can easily be set at an angle afterwards if printed in PLA. Just hold them in 40°C water and you will be able to bend them gently.

The windmill is designed to be motorized using the following 12V DC motor that you can buy at Conrad or Aliexpress etc.

Conrad link for DC motor:

https://www.conrad.nl/nl/modelcraft-rb350200-0a101r-transmissiemotor-12-v-1200-227579.html?sc.ref=Product%20Details

NOTE: This DC motor can be dimmed using a PWM dimmer, but this will reduce the motors life significantly! When using a 1:200 transmission the rotation speed of the windmill will be very realistic when running on 12V.

Once you have printed all the parts I think it will be very obvious how they will fit together, but if it turns out that people have trouble with the assembly, I might produce some assembly instruction here later.

The CAP that has the DC motor inside can be assembled using M3 bolts, in order to be able to do maintenance on the motor.

You could add some LEDs to light up the inside of the windmill.

Dimensions:
Height (body): 400 mm
Total height with blades pointing up: 540 mm
Total blade span: 420 mm.
Width (footprint): 181 mm
Platform width: 276 mm (CR-10 max).

UPDATE



As from 21-2-2018 I have added two missing files called:
FORK SIDE R.STL
and
FORK SIDE L.STL

Happy printing!
Tinkerman

description.text:
This mod is for the Nerf DoubleStrike pistol. Please read all notes before printing, and share the print / notes if you make it! The pin holes might need to be drilled out slightly after printing, I did this to keep a smooth snug fit for the part.

After printing I found the following helps.

  1. place trigger spring in trigger hole (smaller) and line it up with the bigger hole on the trigger.
  2. Slide the trigger axle though the spring & big hole on the trigger shoe.
  3. rotate the trigger so it is almost upsidown then rotate it counter clockwise and you lower the trigger and spring into the frame, this should allow for firm trigger spring. You will have to work the trigger down as you lower it onto the axle.
  4. Have fun!

*READ THIS***
Be sure you take note of the small spring under the trigger when you take aprt the inside of the gun. If you can get a picture of it's correct position, as I guessed as to where it should lay.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print the trigger laying on it's side. Take note one side of the portion that holds the pin is shorter than the other, put the long side down. It prints cleaner standing vertically, however print layers can split due to the tension its experiences inside the nerfgun. Printing on it's side align the layers in a way to prevent this from happening.

PET-G is recommended, as pla might shatter or chip.

description.text:
A collection of 2mm thick blank Eurorack filler panels (or "blind panels", as they are sometimes called). The screw holes are widened a bit to allow more flexible placement. Tested with a TipTop audio case. I had tried some others, downloaded from here, and found the spacing to be off. So I can report these print and fit quite well.

Eurorack is 3U high. The standards used to design these panels was based on the publication by Doepfer, for the A100 series case: http://www.doepfer.de/a100_man/a100m_e.htm

I was able to print these on very high speed, which caused them to be a bit rough. I actually like how it looks, a bit textured.

author: spacekoaster

description.text:
I combined the code from my last two fractals and this is the result.
Changing the size_decrement parameter in the scad file yields bulkier/skinnier versions.
rounded14_fractal_2err.stl was the result of a mistake I made in the script, that connected some points to the center instead of the parent, but I liked the result, so I uploaded it anyway.

I drew up the Anet A6 primary components before putting it together, in case I need to upgrade any of the parts to aluminum later. I figure it might be useful to someone here. Let me know if any of the dimensions are off or if there are any other pieces I need to focus on.

Future plans for the models include:
-Finish drawing all the acrylic parts, including the X axis carriage parts.
-Source/include, all available hardware in the model.

I know not all the dimensions are perfect but most of them match up pretty close.

I have also included a file for screen spacers (mine were too short)

(How does this community not support STEP files?)

to be completely safe you should use pla for all of the partial it will take longer to smooth and form then seal with Urethane

i am not overly concerned with the so called hazards of using ABS and Acetone as it is completely sealed in food safe Urethane

the teeth have ben scaled a little short so the original teeth can mesh first as not to put pressure on the gum line of the dentures

yes i know you can make real dentures i have all the stuff now to make them after all is said and done i have close to $250 in supplies so it is not as cheep as you might think it is to make your own still way better than $1000 per set as to what you would pay to have them made

title: Extrusion Calibration by Calipers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed to recalibrate my extruder steps and wanted to try the SublimeLayers method using calipers attached to the filament. My inexpensive calipers lacked a depth rod so I was unable to use the originally designed holder. They also have a goofy boss at the bottom that will not let them sit flat against a surface (It's the pair that you regret buying even though they were like $4 and you just hold on to hoping that there is something that you can use them for.. this is THAT!). Pretty much any 16m wide standard caliper will do, they can be dial type or electronic. They do not need a depth rod to work.

These calipers would loose count if the caliper body was anywhere near the extruder motor. (I suspect that the reinforced plastic body acts as an antenna and the EM pulses of the motor interfere with the caliper encoder).

So I remixed this so that the caliper holder sits on top of my Di3 sheet metal frame and gets secured with a binder clip. The caliper in turn gets secured with a M3x25 grubscrew.

The clip that captures the filament is similarly secured to the lower jaw of the caliper with 2- M3x10 grub screws. The filament clamp uses an M3x15 screw. I changed the position of the screw so that you do not have to unload the filament from the printer or remove the clamp screw to thread the filament in.

I tweaked the original gcode script, so that the hotend heats up, beeps, displays a countdown and then extrudes 100mm of filament. The extrusion starts off slow and then speeds up then ramps down. See the linked video.

https://youtu.be/RxmVA18I0-0

Tips: Filament is best fed from the top of the printer, or use a short length. It helps if you straighten your filament by running it through your fingers a few times.

If the lower caliper jaw drops a bit after securing the filament and zero'g out the caliper, don't worry about it. The extruder will take up the slack and pull the assembly downwards and it will catch up on the dropped amount.

Remember to calculate the steps per mm and store it to the EEPROM of your printer. Octoprint make this easy for the major firmware flavors. If you are not using already, you should, and if you are, throw a few duckets Gina's way...

I couldn't find a arduino and breadboard holder I liked, so I designed one.

The arduino uno and a half length breadboard should press fit into the slots nicely.

Hope you will enjoy this sexy little hovercraft I designed on my surface pro during lunch hours at work : ) I am not an engineer or a designer so please, feel free to modify at will. I plan to test it on wide open spaces when I find time but I have a feeling based on my very limited testing, that this will fly at pretty impressive speeds...

For this build, you will need:

  • 3 ESCs with 5v BEC or 3 ESCs without BEC with a PDB that can provide a 5v source to power up your receiver, I am using 3 old Turnigy plush 30a ESCs in mine
  • 3 brushless 2205 motors (high kv motors recommended), I am using DYS 2205/2750kv motors as torque is not as important as RPM with the impellers - please note that you may need to modify the impeller wheels to fit your motors height and shaft
  • One 5" 3 blade Quadcopter propeller
  • 1 lipo pack, I recommend a 1500mah 4S battery but 3S is just fine
  • Radio and receiver, I am using a Spektrum DX9 air transmitter and receiver but any surface radio with 4 channels will do as well
  • At least 30 M2 X 8mm self-tapping screws for the skirt retaining rings
  • 6 M2 X 8mm button head screws for the rudders
  • At least 10 M3 X 12mm button or socket head screws for the impeller mounts and the Thrust duct assemblies
  • One 9gm Servo, I m using an EMAX 9g ES08A Mini Servo. You can cut the servo hole to fit any servo you want
  • Tie rod for the rudders
  • Rip-proof nylon fabric, check for the type with waterproof coating. You will need at least one meter long and 15cm wide

Make sure you have some silicon wires to extend your motor wiring and some servo wiring to extend your servo and ESC signal wires. Also and you will need an XT60 connector to hook up your PDB or ESCs to your battery

I am also using an RC tire truer to drill holes to route wiring based on available lengths of your electronics wiring

You need a soldering iron + rosin soldering wire

I have placed my receiver and PDB in the front compartment and made a conduit that leads to the battery and ESC compartment in the back as seen in one of the pictures, there is also space on both sides of the battery compartment to tuck in your ESCs.

There are many ways to get both from impellers to be synchronized, you can either join both impeller ESC to receive signal from one channel or you can program a mix to get both ESCs to perform in any specific way you desire...

This craft will ride on any terrain, grass, asphalt, water, snow... I recommend sealing holes with silicon where you will route wiring underneath the front hull to avoid water or moisture to creep up in the battery and electronics enclosures. I also put in a small desiccant pouch in both compartments in case moisture finds it's way in.

This is an evolution of my previous design found here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2765766

and inspired by Ivan Miranda's superb hovercraft project found on youtube

here is a clip of a short run I made from my garage door, will use it in open space this weekend

https://youtu.be/B8zCXcgk5TM

Please post your build pictures and modify at will - this design can certainly be improved though it is a friggin cool little thing to play with as is...

Enjoy !!!
