title: Playstation Move & Navigation Controller Joiner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In my continuing adventures with sim racing on a budget, I picked up a used Oculus Dev Kit 2 last year. It's great for racing sims, even with a PC that is below the recommended specs for VR, but when I wanted to take a detour into more general VR gaming, I discovered an issue with controls. Oculus' Touch controllers are not incredibly expensive, but they connect wirelessly to something inside the CV1 headset instead of directly to the computer over a standardized protocol, so it isn't usable with the dev kits. I could've maybe tracked down a Razer Hydra set, but the cheapest VR motion controller solution uses Playstation Move controllers: https://github.com/cboulay/PSMoveService/wiki
There are still issues with this setup, such as precision and play area size, but the biggest might be that the standard Move wand is not even close to "button parity" with the newer motion controllers most VR games are designed for. Sony would've had similar issues when initially designing the system, which is why they made the Move Navigation controller, which adds a joystick, D-pad, a second trigger and a shoulder button. However the Navi controller does not have any kind of motion tracking, so you can't play much with a Move wand in one hand and a Navi in the other. What you really want is both in each hand.
There are a lot of ideas on how to do this: https://github.com/cboulay/PSMoveService/wiki/PS-Move-and-Navigation-Controller-United and there are certainly simpler ways than this one. Initially I downloaded freely available 3D models of the Move and Navi controllers and tried to design my own completely 3D printed solution, but either due to plastic warping or inaccuracies in those models, my test print didn't even come close to fitting. I went back to the page I liked to and looked at the pictures from the "DualPlay" crowdfunding campaign. Usually I wouldn't want to rip off an unproduced design from a crowdfunding campaign, but on close inspection you can see that their prototypes were just cut-off parts from Sony Move SharpShooter accessories, glued together by bridges that were probably 3D printed and painted black. (The SharpShooter is the only mass-produced accessory with holders for both the Move wand and Navi controller). Before I started, that seemed like it would be easy enough to copy.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print 1 of each part. Only the top joiner needs support. I printed all parts in ABS with 4 walls and 50% infill for strength.

SharpShooter Teardown

For each one of these you want to make, you need to obtain and destroy a Sony Move SharpShooter. It's a pretty large toy gun, so if you have to buy one online the shipping cost will probably make the project not cost-effective, better to find one locally.

You only need some philips head screwdrivers and maybe a prying tool to get it apart. You'll want to remove and hand on to the two small screws at the front of the Move controller cradle. There's a slide cover thing at the front that is only held on by 3 screws, which should be removed first. The two textured grip panels are actually screwed in from the inside, so don't bother trying to pry them off. Then you can undo all of the screws in the body of the gun. The only "hidden" screws are the ones under caps for the rotary switches on the sides. I started pulling it apart from the top, then worked around the back and to the bottom. If you want to be careful, maybe keep track of where all the springs came from.

For the Navi holder, you want to make your top cut about 8mm past the screw hole. There's a few mm of wiggle room built into my model, so it doesn't have to be perfect or straight. You don't actually want to make the bottom cut where it is on the DualPlay prototype. It turns out there's a bit of spring steel inside there that holds the bottom flap shut. Really, the smart thing to do would be to not cut something before you take it apart and check what's inside.
For the Move holder, your cuts should follow the lines molded into the outside of the plastic. Using Harbor Freight's absolute cheapest rotary tool, these cuts took me 30-45 minutes per side. Probably better to take your time than lose a finger, though.

After cleaning up the cuts, you can reassemble the holders.

Here are your initial toss/keep piles Cut marks Don't cut love too cut Assembly

I designed the joiners to fit over the top of the Navi holder and to just hug the curve at the other 3 points of contact. There are holes for M3x10mm screws, and it seemed solid enough just screwed together, but I glued mine together for extra security.

Mark paper or tape to find the centerpoint for your first hole in the top of the Move holder. I'm not sure what kind of plastic it is, so I drilled a small pilot hole and then worked up through each bit size until the hole was large enough for an M3 screw. Use the screw to attach the top joiner, pop the Navi holder into the other side, and then you should be able to mock up and mark the location for the bottom holder. I drilled the second hole in the Move holder before starting the hole in the Navi holder. The Navi holder is two separate plastic parts, so it is easy to mark the center point but hard to actually drill. There's enough space in the Move holder for screw heads, but I countersunk the hole in the Navi holder. Once you have everything fitting together, you can glue things in place. The "brace" fits into the bottom of the other part of the Move holder. If you followed my instructions you would've cut off everywhere where the two halves screw together, so gluing them back together adds strength back in.

Centering Marking Countersunk If you were careful you can put it back togteher

Small disks with the various Winter Olympic sports and Olympic rings on them. All categories of winter sports on the Olympic website are represented. Files will normally be printed solid-color but filament can be changed after 3.0 mm to set the icon, rings, and outer circle in a secondary color (shown in photos). I am using them to help keep track of sport events for this year's Olympics, although I think they look nice enough to keep around after the Games.

I wouldn't recommend printing the files at <100% size in X,Y as details (rings especially) will likely be lost in slicing. Default dimensions 55 x 55 x 5mm.

UPDATE 3/11/18

title: Anet Spool Holder Conversion and spool adapters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple conversion for the Anet Spool Holder. I wanted it to put a 150mm axle (diameter 8mm) on it instead of the threaded bar. So all you need is two M4 screws and nuts and a 150mm axle, which you can get for a few bucks from aliexpress.
I also made adapters for a few different filament spools, whenever I make new ones, they will be uploaded. You can use 3mm screws to secure the spool on the adapter even though the adapters sit pretty tight. In most cases you won't need them.
Need an adapter for a specific spool? I need the hole diameter and the diameter for the drill holes. As soon as I get to it, I'll make them.

Any ideas, questions, suggestions? Just comment. You made one? I'd love to see some pictures! :)

2018-02-15: Updated the 33mm spool holder, fits better and needs less material.
2018-03-10: Update of Spool with ID 57 and ID 53 and added ID 54

title: Cowboy Nerf Target Gallery
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Have a Blue and Gold banquet coming up, and we decided to do a Western Theme. I decided that it would be a great opportunity to put together a great Nerf target set. It will be mostly able to be disassembled, but still secure. I will post some pictures when it is complete.

All files are fit to my CR-10 Specifications, so each printer may perform differently. You will want one set of the brackets for a triangular based stand, the corner connectors for a back drop, the top crossbeam connectors for connecting to the backdrop, a pair of crossbeam connectors for each level of target, a pair of crossbeam braces for each crossbeam, a pair of target braces for each target, and the circular target spacers if you plan on using the circular target. The only target not up to spec yet is the weighted one as I am still working on getting the screw fitting right. Will post pictures as soon as I have the dowels cut and piece it together.

May want to print connectors at 98-99% as they weren't perfectly compression fit. At 100% the brackets should be excellent.

Not: May want to print extra spacers and braces in case the stray Nerf Dart/Ball dislodges or breaks one.

Printer Brand:

Creality

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

40-50%

Notes:

Target infill: 40% may want to increase that for Mega or Rival Rounds
Brackets, Spacers, Braces, and Connectors: 50% for some structure

I used 1mm top and bottom layers for smoother finish. I will be using PLA and will see durability over the course of the night!

Custom Nerf Target Stand

Created printed targets by first creating a vector graphic in Inkscape. Then I imported the file into TinkerCAD and adjusted scale. Then, I created a small holed pivot point. These will be put on a 5/16 dowel suspended between side posts. The brackets will be created using TinkerCAD to work compression fit with 3/8 in dowels for the side posts, and cross beams that will be the 5/16 compression fit.

My plan for this project is to build the cheapest 3D Printer possible that can deliver better quality than the Ultimaker 3, and I already achieved that goal in the first prototype.

I am currently testing the prototype to know what to fix on the final version and that is where the series will kick off.

This is the best 3D Printer you can currently build from scratch. It is a coreXY design with precision bearings and rods on all 3 axis.

It can be build from an existing hypercube for less than 100$ or from scratch for about 300$ (USD).

From A-Z, I will show everything that goes into designing, building and testing a 3D Printer from the ground up and how to achieve the goal in surpassing ultimaker's print quality.

The build will begin in a few weeks and parts will be uploaded to Thingiverse as the build progresses. I will also release the full CAD files when the time comes (Solidworks and STEP files). Please be patient.

So who's ready to build a 3D Printer together?

STL is only there to be able to pre-publish this project, it is not needed in this build

original instructions:
1) Place the axle guide into the slot that is pre-cut for the nail.
2) You should feel a small lip on each side of the car when the guide is installed properly.
3) Place the car and axle guide into a clamping device to hold both in place.
4) Start the nail into the slot keeping it as aligned as possible while hammering.
5) Hammer the nail firmly and the axle guides will keep the nail going strait.
6) When the wheel contacts the axle guide the nail is in far enough.

author: Novachris

title: Marlin 1.1.8 on CTC prusa i3 DIY (GT2560 rev a)

description.text:
...Español e Italiano a bajo / sotto....

Hello everyone

for Christmas the child Jesus has brought me a 3D printer CTC DIY PRUSA :)

It is a cheap printer and entry level, but enough to make contact with the world of 3D printing.

I am a programmer and I like DIY, so the 3D printer is ideal for me ... but because of this I immediately wanted to update the Firmware and there the first problem. Apparently it can not be done.

Other people have found a way to update the firmware by using another arduino as a programmer on the GT2560 board, but I did not like it at all. Too complicated and I do not have another Arduino board.

So I tried synonymous with the Arduino IDE, to update the firmware via usb, and effectively you can not.
But the error is a "timeout", that is, the computer connects to the gt2560 and recognizes it, but when it sends the data, it does not receive a response.

The error is: "stk500v2_receivemessage timeouts"

investigating the error message, in the end I found that the problem is in the transmission speed, which by default is too high for our gt2560 rev.A.

To lower the transmission speed you have to edit a text file "boards.txt" in our Arduino IDE, restart the IDE, reload the firmware and send it to the printer via usb.

Here is a video that explains perfectly how to modify the "boards.txt" file of the arduino IDE to work with our gt2560

EDIT: see below, I wrote how to do it

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIu8_wYG0Y4

The video is for OSX, but it works also for linux and windows, since the Arduino IDE is multi platform.
The route of the file may vary a bit, but the "boards.txt" file is the same for every OS.

I leave my version of Marlin 1.1.8 (the last stable at the time I write these notes), so you do not have to fight with the configuration of the LCD, the measurements in mm, the extruder and several other things.

In this version of Marlin:

Save / Read the configuration in the EEPROM
Fixed the STEPS / mm, so if you tell him to print a piece of 100mm, it comes out of 100mm without having to modify the size in the mesh or increase in CURA to 102% the proportions.
Change Automatic filament, so you can insert a color change (M600) at a certain height in the gcode, also from the control panel.
Progress bar
scrolling file name, when long

I do not have a decent noise meter, but it seems to me that the 3d printer makes less noise with the marlin 1.1.8 compared to 1.1.6.

ciao
MaX

EDIT (pasted from comment)

How to install this firmware on our 3D printer:

go to download the last Arduino IDE from here: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software

Once installed or unzipped, modify this file with a simple text editor:
ArduinoIDE/hardware/arduino/avr/boards.txt
The route may vary a bit depending on the operating system. In any case, look for the file "boards.txt"

edit the boards.txt file to this line from:
mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed = 115200

to

mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed = 57600

Connect your printer to the USB door and turn it on

Launch the Arduino IDE and change in the Tools menu, selecting

Board: Arduino / Mega Genuino or Mega 2560
Processor: ATMega 2560

Then load firmware 1.1.8 from the File / Open menu and look in the folder you just unzipped (it's a tar.gz that is decompressed as a .zip), the file "Marlin.ino"

Almost there!

Click on the icon "Arrow" (right under the Edit menu) and if everything went well in a minute you will have the new firmware running on your printer.

Notes:
In windows it will be necessary to also select which USB port to use and possibly install some drivers. Search on the internet how to fix this typical windows problem.

geeetech GT2560: https://www.geeetech.com/wiki/index.php/GT2560

Hola a todos

por Navidad el niño Jesús me ha traido una impresora 3D CTC DIY PRUSA :)

Es una impresora barata y entry level, pero suficiente para tomar contacto con el mundo de la impresión 3D.

Soy programador y me gusta el bricolage, así que la impresora 3D es lo ideal para mi... pero proprio por esto en seguida he quierido actualizar el Firmware y allí el primer problema. Al parecer no se puede hacer.

Otras personas han encontrado la forma de actualizar el firmware utulizando otro arduino como programador de la placa GT2560 de mi impresora, pero no me gustaba nada. Demasiado complicado y no tengo otra placa de arduino.

Así que he intentado igualmente con el IDE de arduino actualizar el firmware via usb, y efectivamente no se puede, pero el error es un timeout, o sea el ordenador se conecta con la gt2560 y la reconoce, pero cuando le invia los datos, no recibe respuesta de recibido.

el error es: "stk500v2_receivemessage timeouts"

investigando el mensaje de error, al final he encontrado que el problema está en la velocidad de transmisión, que por defecto es demasiado elevada para nuestra gt2560 rev.A.

Para bajar la velocidad de transmisión hay que editar un fichero de texto "boards.txt" en nuestro IDE de Arduino, reiniciar el IDE, volver a cargar el firmware y enviarlo a la impresora via usb.

Aquí hay un video que explica perfectamente como modificar el fichero "boards.txt" del IDE de arduino para que funcione con nuestra gt2560

EDIT: Mira a bajo donde explico como hacerlo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIu8_wYG0Y4

El vídeo es para OSX, pero funciona también para linux y windows, puesto que el IDE de Arduino es multi plataforma.
Puede variar un poco el recorrido del fichero, pero el fichero "boards.txt" es igual para todos.

Os dejo junto mi versión de Marlin 1.1.8 (la última estable en el momento que escribo estas notas), así que no teneis que pelearos con la configuración del LCD, de las medidas en mm, del extrusor y varias otras cosas.

En esta versión de Marlin:

Guardar y Leer La confguración desde la EEPROM
Arreglado los STEPS por mm, así que cuando imprimes una pieza de por ejempo 100mm, te sale de 100mm, sin tener que modificar el diseño o poner en CURA las proporciones al 102%
Cambio Automático del filamento, así puedes insertar un cambio de color dentro del gcode (M600) a una determinada altura y también cambiar el filamento desde el panel de control
Barra de progreso
Nombre del archivo desplazable, cuando es largo

no tengo un medidor de ruido decente, pero me parece que la impresora 3d, hace menos ruido con el marlin 1.1.8 respecto al 1.1.6.

ciao
MaX

Añadido desde un comentario:

Como instalar este firmware en nuestra impresora 3D:

ir a descargar el Arduino IDE más recién desde aquí: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software

una vez instalado o descomprimido modificar con un editor de texto simple este fichero:
ArduinoIDE/hardware/arduino/avr/boards.txt
El recorrido puede variar un poco según el sistema operativo. De todas forma busca el fichero "boards.txt"

edita el fichero boards.txt a esta linea desde:

mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed=115200

a

mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed=57600

Conecta tu impresora a la puerta USB y enciendela

Lanza el Arduino IDE y cambia en el menu Tools, seleccionando:

Board: Arduino/Mega Genuino o Mega 2560
Processor: ATMega 2560

Luego carga el firmware 1.1.8 desde el menu File/Open y busca en la carpeta que acaba de descomprimir (es un tar.gz que se descomprime como un .zip), el fichero "Marlin.ino"

¡Ya falta poco!

Pulsa el icono "Flecia" (justo a bajo del menu Edit) y si todo ha ido bien en un minuto ya tendrás el firmware nuevo corriendo en tu impresora.

Notas:
En windows habrá que seleccionar también que puerto usb hay que usar y posiblemente habrá que instalar unos drivers. Busca en internet como arreglar este tipico problema de windows.

geeetech GT2560: https://www.geeetech.com/wiki/index.php/GT2560

Ciao a tutti

per Natale il bambino Gesù mi ha portato una stampante 3D CTC DIY PRUSA :)

È una stampante economica e di fascia bassa, ma è sufficiente per entrare in contatto con il mondo della stampa 3D.

Sono un programmatore e mi piace il fai-da-te, quindi la stampante 3D è l'ideale per me ... ma proprio per deformazione professionale ho immediatamente voluto aggiornare il firmware... e lì il primo problema. Apparentemente non si può!

Altre persone hanno trovato un modo per aggiornare il firmware usando un altro arduino come programmer collegato alla scheda GT2560, ma non mi piaceva affatto. Troppo complicato ed inoltre non ho un'altra scheda Arduino da usare.

Così ho provato anche io con l'IDE di Arduino, ad aggiornare il firmware via USB, e in effetti non è possibile farlo.
Ma l'errore è un "timeout", cioè il computer si connette al gt2560 e la riconosce, ma quando invia i dati, non riceve una risposta.

L'errore è: "stk500v2_receivemessage timeouts"

indagando sul messaggio di errore, alla fine ho scoperto che il problema è nella velocità di trasmissione, che di default è troppo alta per il nostro gt2560 rev.A.

Per ridurre la velocità di trasmissione è necessario modificare un file di testo "boards.txt" nel nostro IDE di Arduino, riavviare l'IDE, ricaricare il firmware e inviarlo alla stampante tramite USB.

Ecco un video che spiega perfettamente come modificare il file "boards.txt" dell'IDE di arduino per funzionare con il nostro gt2560

EDIT: Più in basso ho aggiunto come fare

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIu8_wYG0Y4

Il video è per OSX, ma funziona anche per linux e windows, dal momento che l'IDE di Arduino è multipiattaforma.
Il percorso del file può variare un po', ma il file "boards.txt" è uguale per tutti.

Lascio la mia versione di Marlin 1.1.8 (l'ultima stabile al momento in cui scrivo queste note), quindi non occorre litigare con la configurazione del display LCD, le misure in mm, l'estrusore e molte altre cose.

In questa versione di Marlin:

Salvare e leggere la configurazione dalla EEPROM
regolato gli STEPS per mm, in modo che quando stampi un pezzo da per esempio 100mm, ti esce da 100mm senza dover modificare il disegno o aumentare le proporzione al 102% in CURA
Cambio Automatico del filamento, cosí puoi forzare un cambio di colore direttamente dal gcode (M600), oppure dal pannello di controllo
Barra di progresso
nome del file scorrevole, quando è troppo lungo

Non ho un misuratore di rumore decete, ma a orecchio mi sembra che la stampate faccia meno rumore con questo ultimo marlin 1.1.8 rispetto al vecchio 1.1.6

ciao
MaX

Aggiunto da un commento

Come installare questo firmware sulla nostra stampante 3D:

vai a scaricare l'IDE Arduino piú reciente da qui: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software

Una volta installato o decompresso, modifica questo file con un semplice editor di testo:
ArduinoIDE / hardware / arduino / avr / boards.txt
Il percorso può variare leggermente a seconda del sistema operativo. In ogni caso, cerca il file "boards.txt"

modifica il file boards.txt in questa riga da:
   mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed = 115200

a

   mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed = 57600

Collega la stampante alla porta USB e accendila

Avvia l'IDE Arduino e imposta nel menu Tools, selezionando

Scheda: Arduino / Mega Genuino o Mega 2560
Processore: ATMega 2560

Quindi carica il firmware 1.1.8 dal menu File / Apri e cerca nella cartella appena decompressa (è un tar.gz che è decompresso come .zip), il file "Marlin.ino"

Manca poco!

Fare clic sull'icona "Freccia" (proprio sotto il menu Modifica) e se tutto è andato bene in un minuto, il nuovo firmware verrà eseguito sulla tua stampante 3D.

note:
In Windows sarà necessario anche selezionare quale porta USB usare e possibilmente installare alcuni driver. Cerca su internet come risolvere questo tipico problema di Windows.

geeetech GT2560: https://www.geeetech.com/wiki/index.php/GT2560

title: Customizable FitBit Flex Arc Band UPDATED

description.text:
My previous, flexible Fitbit band works great for me, but my wife wanted something a bit thinner, so I came up with this. It's a simple, solid arc that fits around your wrist, with a cutout to precisely fit the Fitbit Flex. Customize to your own wrist size! Updated:
  • added a 'width' parameter, so that you can make the band wider.
  • added support for unlimited width, so you can make a crazy wide band if you like. Uploaded example STL.

Click 'customize'.
Enter your wrist measurement, in either inches or mm (but not both).
Click on the "Solid Band" tab, and tweak the settings until you like it.
Generate and print it! There's an option to 'include support' in the model. You should use this, unless you're using software that does a particularly good job of generating support structures inside the hole It will put a single thin "wall" in the middle of the area where the Fitbit goes, which will have to be removed. The Fitbit is a tight fit (pressure holds it in place) so make sure that you clean the support structures out well. Insert the Fitbit Flex by sliding it up into the band, thicker end first, so that the ends are held in place in the holes in the band. The lights should facing the outside of the band, through the wider hole. To remove the Fitbit, press it out by pressing through the smaller hole. Have fun!

comments.text: I've printed both with and without supports. I'm not sure how to cleanup up the area where the Fitbit goes without ruining the whole thing.
comments.author: scottdswingle

comments.text: I use the Simplify3D slicer, which generates supports that are very easy to remove. You can also select "include supports" in Customizer and it will include some easy to remove supports into the design. Makerware's generated support is much harder to remove.

print_settings.Notes:: Set the first layer thickness to 0.2mm in your slicer of choice. To calibrate different heights, just scale the STL in Z only (e.g., 50% for 0.1mm; 150% for 3mm).

description.text:
I'm not a fan of using thickness gauges for bed-leveling.
I'm never sure how much resistance is ideal, or whether my paper is the right thickness, and what effect my glue stick has.
This avoids all that, and allows me to take direct measurements of the printed layer.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm Layers

Infill:

Concentric

Notes:
  1. Set the first layer thickness to 0.2mm in your slicer of choice. To calibrate different heights, just scale the STL in Z only (e.g., 50% for 0.1mm; 150% for 3mm).
  2. Set the infill style to Concentric if possible (more continuous extrusion, makes for very flat reference surfaces).
    2.5 (Optional) Set your "wall line count" to 0 (fewer moves means flatter reference surfaces).
  3. Print the thing.
  4. Without removing the print from the tray, use a depth gauge or the depth function of your calipers to check the thickness of each piece.
    If you don't have access to a depth gauge (why are you reading this lol), you can remove the pieces - but then you need to keep track of which is which (which sucks).
  5. Adjust the leveling screws.
  6. Repeat until satisfied!

Another headset hanger. I wanted one a bit beefier than others I had found. This has radiused corners, gusseted, and a screw hole in case you need it. Inside gap for the desk is 1.030 printed on my A8.

Curiosity is the biggest, baddest, laser-wielding,  plutonium-powered, robot-rover ever sent to Mars. On Sunday, August 5, 2012 it survived a dangerous landing that secured Mars exploration hopes for a decade. It will help answer the question of whether or not we are alone in the universe. Why not print this fearless hero for your desk?
(Excellent paint job and photo courtesy of Adam1mc.)
Update 12/30/12: Fixed a lot of the parts in netfabb to better print on those picky printers. Leave a comment if you still have trouble.
Update 10/8/12: Freely spinning wheels! Just break them off and drive away - no extra pegs! Working rocker to allow the wheels to go over big Martian bumps while keeping all wheels on the ground! Updated head/neck connection that fits better and has fewer pieces.
Update 8/6/12: Updated body file that is much more accurate and detailed (with artistic license, of course).
Update 8/5/12: Fixed head file where one part was not touching the build platform.

• Print all files: Head, Body, Wheels, and Arm. You may need to print with a raft because many pieces are very small.
  • Blow some air across the print right as it is finishing the mast (neck). This will keep that hole printing round, otherwise, it might sag a little and you'll have to drill it out.
  • Break the supports off the back of the wheels. They're just there for printing. The wheels won't be able to spin freely with those posts sticking out the back.
  • Break the wheels loose by wiggling them back and forth, then gently twisting. Be careful not to wiggle them so hard that you also break off the axel. There's some play but not tons. They're only connected at the bottom.
  • Break loose the rocker by gently twisting back and forth.
  • Assemble the parts. The rocker part of the wheel mount goes to the back. You can pose this lady in your favorite martian scene!
  • Watch the landing videos or watch the awesome simulation videos from NASA. Check out the latest images of what Curiosity has discovered on Mars!
    • Leave feedback and ideas in the comments! Want to design a funny new head for Curiosity? The mast hole is 8mm in diameter.

description.text: very cool!

A four drawer dresser, modeled after the discontinued IKEA Mandal style dresser, modeled at 12:1 scale.

Printing

The drawers and the face plates for the drawers are printed separately, so no supports are required; this does, however, require gluing. I've tested this print with 0.20mm layers and 20% infill.

  • Print 1x of the small drawer and small drawer face
  • Print 3x of the large drawer and large drawer face
  • Print 1x of the dresser main

Assembling

For best assembly slide the drawers into place without face plates, and set the dresser on its back. Apply glue to the front edge of a drawer, a single drawer at a time, and align and press face plate into place. Repeat for all four drawers.

Scaling

I haven't tested this print at anything other than 12:1 scale, so modifications or alterations may be needed to print at other common model scales. This is especially true for the rack and runners of the drawers, which may shrink down below printable dimensions if scaled down to far.

For 18:1 scale, print at 66% of model scale.

For 24:1 scale, print at 50% of model scale.

author: shashickt

description.text: A small temple for placing the god models

This year, we're using a few redline motors on our robot. They're the kind of motor that have tabs you solder the wire to, but they seem a bit delicate and easy to get torn off if a lose wire got caught on something. To protect the motor and our service loop, I created a cover to keep the tabs and loop nice and safe.
When you put it on, you might need a layer or two of electrical tape depending on the motor, pahse of the moon, days untill next leap year, ect.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

100 %

Notes:

If you use the model with what looks like tubes running all over, dont use supports, the tubes are supports. Otherwise, you'll need to create your own supports.
First layer hieght is 0.36 mm.

You will need to remove the supports, which for me was a bit of a pain.

Step One: Remove "looser" supports

Us a pair of needlenose pliers or simailer to remove the majority of the support on the outside and inside of the cover. Dont go crazey trying to get supports that stick too strongly, they''ll come of in one of the other steps.

Step Two: Remove supports from the cuttouts

Use a scratch awl/ center punch and hammer to punch out the supports from inside the cutouts and any strgglers you couldn't get with the pliers (except the ones where the raft was, leave those for the next step). I find it helpful to put the cover in a vice and lightly - I repeat- lightly clamp in in and let it settle to the bottom, then tap the supports out.

Step Three: Remove the supports from where the raft was

Usually, I use a chisle to remove supports like this, but had trouble executing. Instead, I held the peice in a pair of vise-grips and used a belt sander to remove them, which leaves a rough, woodstained section, but is probably smoother (and certanly faster) than trying to get them off with pliers.

This tutorial is designed to work to make a cover for any motor you may have, using the redline motor as an example. Screenshots were taken in Onshape.

Step One (a): Create the main body

On whatever plane you choose, create a sketch consisting of a line half the diamiter of your motor plus relief (e.g. [(1.77/2 in)+0.25 mm]) from the origin and as long as you want your cover to be tall ( because part of the purpose of my cover was to proect a service loop, I left a lot of room up there). Also create a rounded top as tall or flat as you wish. The top is pretty unimportant and you can just eyeball it. I like to fillet the connection between the line and the arc to make it nice and smooth.

(b)

Offset this entire sketch as thick as you see fit, I used 0.15 in. Also connect the offset sketch to the original one with a line, and be careful with the top arc. Make sure that line is parellel with whichever direction is "up" and even with the offset arc, then connect those two lnes with another line (see close up picture).

Don't forget to connect the two arcs properly! (c)

Revolve that sketch a full 360 degrees into a new solid, using the line parrellel to the "up" direction and in the center of where the solid will be as the revolve axis.

Step Two (a): Make cutouts for air cerculation and wire routing.

After offseting a plane the radius of the hollow cylinder you've created, sketch slots for any air circualation cutouts in your motor. If you're making a cover for a sealed motor, like a CIM, dont worry about air. You can find the distance for your cutouts by eyeballing with a caliper or ruler about how far up they start and stop, and to make it nice rounding off the edges with arcs.

(b)

Take any sketches you made for cutouts and extrude them all the way through, or use emboss if your software has it, which is a feature Onshape lacks. Another, much more annoying thing to be witho is the abillity to pattern your holes, so the only way to get more cutouts is to duplicate you sketch onto a perpendicular plane and extrude it through again. I don't think you can rotate the part or make a plane wuth a costum angle, but if I'm wrong please correct me.

(c)

Now you'll need cutouts for your wire to exit from, unless you're cool with them coming through the other cutouts (i think that looks messy). Create two lines. The distance between them is equal to the diamiter of your wire plus relief. Make them as long as the diamiter of your wire times two plus relief, then round the edges with arcs to make it nice. Extrude this, but not all the way through. I also like to add one coming out the top so you've got options. The diamier of the hole I extrude out the top is the diamiter of the wire times two plus relief.

Step Three: Add finishing touches

I like to chamfer all of the parts you'll have to stick things through or into to make it easier to align. I chamfered the large opening for the motor to go through and the two wire routing holes.

Congrats, you're done!

Enjoy your cosutom motor cover, maybe even engrave your team name or number on it!

title: Mini Prusa Dampers with Holes for Base-Mounting

description.text:
I was designing an enclosure for my Prusa i3 mk2, and came across hofftari's mounts. I wanted to be able to screw them into my base so they'd be in the exact position I wanted it within the enclosure's walls, so I made some holes in his design.

I used 4 #6 x 5/8" pan head screws. Put them together first, mark where you want them. Slip the inside piece out just enough so that the screw can fit through the hole on the bottom, and then slip the screw and inside piece into the outside. Make a hole in the felt pads and drive the screw through. Put the screwdriver through the hole on the top to screw it in place.

I recommend drilling a little hole where you're screwing, so it drives in easier and straight down.

*I used nylon filament, so I don't know if ABS/PLA will work well with the holes...leave a comment if it works out for you.

author: Thingismith

description.text:
This is a quick stiffener that clips on the back of the frame of an a8. My particular a8 is a sainsmart.

I see a lot of people cussing because they run a long print on an A8 accessory just to find out theirs is a a little different dimension than the designers. This design is very versitile. as long as the acrylic frame is 8mm your set. Now - That being said - this one uses a piece of wood. I have a table saw and scrap plywood floating around. This might be hard for some to hear but you can make parts for your printer with tools that are not printers.

I glued the plywood to the clips. It just clips to the back. It does make a huge difference in how wiggly the frame is. My print quality went way up real quick.

Just for the record - the printer is in the attic, nested amongst the old sweaters and the christmas stuff. My shop is messy, but it's not that messy.
Print the tire in something semi-flexible and stretch it over the wheel.
This is to help hold the vtx mast more steady in a crash.

title: Flying Pig Mobile
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Flying Pig Mobile: desktop or free hanging

This is a flying pig mobile. This can be either a desktop mobile or a (simpler) free hanging mobile.

The xml files used to create the geometry in BlocksCAD are also provided for the stand and arm, but not the flying pig and wing.

FREE HANGING MOBILE

PRINT INSTRUCTIONS FOR FREE HANGING MOBILE:

piggies:

  • print 3 piggy bodies: flying_pig_140409a_x_0.4_flatfoot.stl
  • print 3 wings: wing_140411c_x_0.4.stl

mobile arm:

  • print 1 mobile arm: mobile_arm_flying_pigs.stl

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS FOR THE FREE HANGING MOBILE:

  • paint the piggy nose and ears red
  • paint the eyeballs white all over
  • paint the nostrils and eyeball pupils black

  • glue wing to piggy body

  • use strong black thread to attach piggies to mobile arms

  • attach strong thread to top of mobile arm

  • hang at a convenient location

  • black thread is recommend vs string so that the mobile can spin easier

  • to start the motion, gently spin the top of the mobile arm

DESKTOP MOBILE:

in addition to the steps for the free hanging mobile:

ALSO PRINT:

  • base: stand_for_snowflake_mobile (28) base.stl
  • straight connector: stand_for_snowflake_mobile (31) con straight.stl
  • lower arm: stand_for_snowflake_mobile (27) lower arm.stl
  • curved connector: stand_for_snowflake_mobile (35) con curved.stl
  • upper arm: stand_for_snowflake_mobile (21) upper arm.stl

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS:

  • connect the lower arm to the base using the straight connector
  • connect the upper arm to the lower arm using the curved connector
  • hang the free hanging mobile from the hole at the top
    of the upper arm

description.text: This is a remix of Link's Master Sword (one of the better ones I found here) to print right off the bat very easily. I've also added connectors and cleaned up the geometry.

Just another three digit dial life / HP counter. Print one of the Body and End Cap, two of the "Separators", and three of the "Number Wheels". Then slife a number wheel on the center shaft of the body, slide on a separator, then the next number wheel, then the next separator, then the last number wheel, and the end cap. Only glue in the peg holes near the base on the body and separators, otherwise the number wheels can get fused. It's also a pleasant suggestion to print the number wheels a separate color from the rest of the dial.

It might be a little tricky to slide on the number wheels and end cap, because of the 'bars' across the top. just bend those bars out slightly, very carefully, during assembly. Also, all files load in the proper orientation in Craftware, not sure about in other slicers.

description.text: A simple object made for clamping your headset to your desk.

print_settings.Notes:: I'd print this with 2 to 3 layers max. The idea is to keep the vent cover as light as possible, but still have a little strength. Depending on where you're using it, PLA or ABS could both be used. For a hinge, I designed it to take a 1.5mm rod. The holes in the fins are EXACTLY 1.5mm, so you'll most likely have to heat up whatever you're using with a lighter. This was intentional to hold them in place. However, the grooves in the bracket are 1.8mm and should allow the hinge to swing freely. I used #17 x 1 inch nails from Walmart and cut the heads off with a dremel. If it doesn't move freely enough once assembled I'd recommend cleaning out the holes on the vent holder with a small drill bit and twisting with your fingers. You can also add a bit of sewing machine oil to the nails/hinges.

description.text:
UPDATE: The files for this with updated 2/15 with some minor, but important tweaks. If you've downloaded this I'd recommend re-downloading it now.

I recent built an enclosure for printing hotter materials like ABS. To prevent cold air from working it's way up the vent hose and slow hot air from leaking out I put a surgical mask over the vent hole. I only had to experiment one night before i realized the surgical mask was restricting too much airflow from the fan. Since my vent goes to a window, but is still behind a screen, I needed a solution to be fairly low profile. I designed this vent cover to prevent back drafts by only swinging one way. When venting, the cover opens allowing unrestricted air flow. This was designed for a 4 inch hole but could probably be used up to 4.5. Anything smaller obviously will work fine as well.

description.text:
This isn't a significant change from the original ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2545456 ) by droton, but I added a ridge to it so the sunglasses (or my regular glasses) would "clip" into the clip.

I was was driving home from work in the fog that comes from teaching middle school all day, and I almost had a heart attack when my Oakley Gascan sunglasses landed on my head as I was coming up to a stoplight. The original clip had been doing an amazing job, but I think the arms on my sunglasses were a little too thick for it, and the arms on my normal glasses were a little too thin.
When I got home, I used Microsoft 3D Builder to merge a small cylinder with the section that holds the glasses. My sunglasses will still shake loose and move around a bit, but the ridge now prevents them form falling. I can now also use the visor without worrying about them coming down.

description.text: Brackets designed in Fusion360 to allow custom shelf design. I built a shelf for my office (see pictures) which was a huge hit.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Assembly instructions:

Please note before starting, it is best to assemble the pieces with it laying flat on the floor (like the shelf has fallen over) so that the back support brackets can be attached before standing it up. Without the back brackets, you will not have a very sturdy shelf and any weight added to it will result in tears… yours.

I chose to make a pretty hefty hex grid of shelves as you can see in the picture, but you can modify and make whatever design you want. My support brackets are only designed for the hex arrangement and if you alter, you may need to design and print some brackets depending on your design to help support it. There was quite a bit of printing to get this design. The bigger the shelf, the more you’ll be printing… I used 6 full 1kg spools of white filament by the time I was done.

The wood measurements for me below:

Main shelf length 240mm
Back support strip length 205mm, width 15mm. Orientate so you see the edge towards you.
Baltic Plywood Thickness 1/2 inch (or 12.5mm)
I used 1/2 inch white tipped screws for the construction. You only need to go in one side of the bracket, not both.

Printing the brackets, I decided not to have the top and bottom layers filled in. I chose a honeycomb pattern as it matched the overall design. You will need to experiment with your printer to get the strongest results. I used 9 perimeters, no top or bottom, and 30% infill. I printed on both my Prusa MK3 and MK2s.

Depth of shelf is up to you… I made mine 6” deep, that way I could get all the pieces I needed from 1 4’x8’ sheet of plywood. I used Baltic Birch as it has a nice edge after being cut. Don’t forget about the kerf (thickness) of the blade when making cuts to make sure you get accurate measurements. The depth of your shelf could be at least 8” before needing to print a middle bracket for support.

I stained the back support to give it extra contrast, up to you if you want to do the same.

If you use these brackets and post, please credit me @vfxsoup (for instagram) for my design. Initial inspiration came from looking at a great design by martcaset (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2400175) . Good luck, it was a really fun project printing all the parts and putting it together. Leave a comment if you have any questions and I'll try to help.

author: Jace1969

description.text:
Filament spool holder that can be mounted under a desk, holds the spool horizontally. The top plate is attached to the bottom of the desk using screws or double sided tape. The lower holder goes through the spool and snaps magnetically to the top plate. The lower part and spool rotates around the thrust bearing. Useful for those who have issues with keeping horizontal surfaces clear.

There are two different spool posts, a short version that works with most narrow spools or spools with an inset (e.g. Atomic Filament), and a longer version that works with most spools, including the wider ones.

Uses a 14mm thrust bearing* and 15mm magnets*. I used 3 magnets on top and 5 on the bottom, that should be strong enough for 1kg spools, but more can be used for a more secure attachment. The magnets are pressed into the plastic using crush ribs, the thrust bearing is held in by the magnets.

More spool holders and other of my designs for 3D printers can be found here

Printed in Atomic Filament Pastel Lilac and Pearlescent Blue PLA.

*affiliate links

I had a bunch of these 25mm X-BET magnets laying around: http://a.co/3MEjAsl

Made this to hold them and added right angle screw holes so I could secure them to the LACK tables. Doubles as an inside stop for the door. I used a drill to remove some of the inner walls in the corner of the poly-carbonate and slipped the magnet in between, friction fit is plenty to keep it there.

now just to chat a little... is this as good as a real metal mic stand??? uhhh not really to be honest. The thread pitch to have a big strong coarse thread is a loose pitch so the clamping force is not super high, which means the caliper isn't rock solid in the base. but that being said it's definitely solid enough to take a good measurement! Works good for me. One little hack if you want a more secure clamp is to put a little rubber pad on the base side of the clamp jaws.

Print the parts rather solid like 4 to 6 shells with ~50% infill. Or more solid if you have the time.

I used PLA. Nylon if you have it would be a good choice for the knob and nut because of the low coef. of friction but I don't have nylon. PLA works fine.

description.text:
This is a character I extracted from the game Fallout: New Vegas. In a post apocalyptic world it's hard to tell who is a friend and who is a foe. Securitrons keep the peace on the New Vegas strip and "help" to guide you on your way... Or do they?   
Print out your own Securitron and be ready for the apocalypse!   
Speaking of the Apocyalypse... This doesn't apparently print anymore / on many units. I am working on a remix, but in the meantime, I wouldn't suggest printing it out unless you try to repair the model.

This is my first model so it will need cleaning up and further improvements will be made as I become more familiar with 3D modeling. On my wish list of improvements are to make a base for the unit, fix the wiring so that it prints with the unit (currently the come off too easily while removing support material) and reduce the amount of support material necessary. Also, the hands need some improvement as does the antenna. It's fairly fragile in those parts so I would be careful.   
Constructive comments are welcome and deviations from the design are fully welcome! I borrowed it from Bethesda so it's only fair other people can change it too.

Minimal extruder housing for use with the Printrbot Gearhead drive gears, 1.75mm filament, and a NEMA14 motor.

The secondary gear is inserted from the side, and the additional M3 screws or setscrews hold the gear in place and adjust the tension. It's designed to use a bowden coupler from RobotDigg. Make sure the setscrew doesn't stick out on the primary drive gear, especially if using a motor without a D-shaft.

Filament is Emerald Green PETG from Atomic Filament.

There is also a NEMA17 version and info about several other dual drive bowden extruders I've just uploaded on thrinter.com

title: SimplifyVR Ultra360 x10F 360 Rig Panoramic Camera Mount for GoPro and similar action cameras

description.text:
We are slowly releasing all of the designs for our 360 rigs here on Thingiverse -- we have sold many but the market is slowing down for 360 rigs while our threaded inserts used in them are getting more and more popular. We hope releasing the STL files freely will encourage greater adoption of our designs, and we intend to continue supplying the inserts for the long term, and the COTS components for at least the medium term.

This is a 10-camera 360 rig designed for the GoPro Hero4 but will with with many different cameras that can use GoPro-style quick-detach brackets. It worked well for us while we were based in Alaska. Now that we are based in Georgia (the state), we don't come across many scenes worthy of 360 photography :-(

This rig can be waterproof if used with individual waterproof housings, but we have another rig (to be released on Thingiverse soon) designed specifically for waterproof housings (hero4 only). This rig works great with the frame housings.

For good deals on the aluminum quick-detach brackets and frame housings, look for our store "Albers LLC" on eBay. There are models for the brackets available from other users on thingiverse. Printed ones work "well enough", maybe give them a try before buying our aluminum ones. If you use this enough, you'll want the metal ones. Printed brackets are fine for occasional light use and make this almost fully printed besides the threaded inserts.

You will also need a variety of threaded inserts -- which is now our primary product line.
These are available on both eBay and Amazon.
The top/bottom use 1/4-20 (short) inserts, and each WD mount requires 3 #8-32 inserts.
The top and bottom plates connect to the core with #8-32 inserts. We are expanding our fastener catalog but for now we suggest buying fasteners from wherever you would normally buy them.
Our eBay listings are here:
http://stores.ebay.com/Albers-LLC?_dmd=2&_nkw=inserts
while our Amazon listings can be found by searching for "initeq inserts"

description.text:
This design is a quick test of a single-row omniwheel that attempts to maximize the number of rollers (for smoother rolling) while also maximizing the roller diameter (for easier transverse motions). It has an roller diameter to O.D. ratio of 4:1, and uses 26 rollers that leaves less than a 14 degree gap between rollers. Overall, it has a 3" diameter and a hub with a 5mm bore.

All 26 rollers snap into place without the need for any separate axles.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20% on body, 30% on all others
clean up edges so the parts slide together easily but not loosely

Assembly tips

Assembly, first, use no glue. If needed, the legs. frame and body clips can accept a #4 screw to secure them tightly together if required. The frame STL files include sacrificial pads to aid adhesion. Use scissors or side cutters to remove and clean up edge with a file. DO NOT bend and tear as this can cause layer splitting. The frames flat side faces the bottom of the H501, insert a body clip in each corner facing to opposite corner, I faced the little tabs towards the center but either way is fine. Sand as required to fit each clip in the frame, don't use force. Add a leg to each corner but add no screws yet, face them flaring outwards. As with the clips, don't force them on, sand as required. feet are a personal option, bare, snow free or friendly as you please. Secure the feet with the pin and secure the pin with a safety wire. doesn't have to be hard wire, copper wire or something formable will work. Having extra pins, wire and something to cut the wire if field repairs or changes become necessary. Enjoy.

description.text: Found that there was no upper right leg file, so I flipped left A and B, and created them into a single file.

Dual motor, dual drive bowden extruder. Uses two NEMA14 motors and two drive gears. The two motors should be wired to run in opposite directions, and can be wired in serial or parallel (I would tend to wire the motors in series on a 24V printer and parallel on the 12V printer, but it will also depend on the motors and drivers).

Two screws are used to adjust the gap between the gears, or small springs* can be used for a constant tension configuration.

Here are the parts I used:

  • 2 x 0.8A NEMA14 Motors
  • 2 x Knurled extruder gears*
  • 1 x M5 Heat set brass insert
  • 1 x M5 threaded bowden coupler - not the one I used, but the closest match I could find
  • M3 Screws (eight M3x20 socket cap screws)

More info about several other dual drive bowden extruders I've just uploaded on thrinter.com

Printed in Inland Translucent Yellow PETG*

*affiliate link

description.text:
Time lapse of this being printed: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1n17giCYl3hotwhxVetOzgv-r-7p_CNCJ/view?usp=sharing

This is a clarinet reed case I designed, and it works really well! Let me know what you think, and consider following me if you like this project.

  1. Grooves in the case allow moisture to escape from the reed to prevent warping.
  2. It holds 4 reeds, and is the most compact case design I could think of.
  3. I have dropped this on tile many times, but it doesn't break.
  4. Nothing can beat a 3D printed reedcase! I encourage you to change the words on the side of the case to say your name, chair number, etc. This way it will be distinctly yours.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm or thinner

Notes:

Print the nameplate and case body separately from each other. Orient the body as the picture and linked video show. Supports are not needed, although it is necessary to use a 0.5 cm or 1 cm skirt around the body of the case. The skirt adds extra surface area to the part. This way, it will not tip over towards the end of the print.

After You Print

Although this isn't strictly necessary, I recommend wet sanding this case with fine sandpaper before putting reeds in it. This way, you are sure to not break the tip on this case's uneven surface.

Print the nameplate separate from the case. I used superglue to attach the plate onto the case afterwards, and the plate makes the case much more interesting to look at.

This is the kryptonite knuckles used by Batman in injustice 2.

For printing make sure to use a brim and supports everywhere!

I designed this using fusion 360, I first found a top view picture of the knuckles and placed it on the design part of fusion 360. I scaled it to size by right clicking the picture name on the left of the screen. I then used the sketch tool to trace the outline, and specific parts of the object. I extruded this to a good size height, and put chamfers and filets on the pieces in which it seemed needed. It was especially hard to put chamfers on the curved parts of the object, and some edits were needed. I also used the modify > press pull option to put indents in some parts of the object.

Masking Tape Dispenser

Designed for Home Depot 0.20” plywood and cut on a Glowforge.
Design created in 123D.
Material thickness designed at 5.2mm.
Design is made as zero clearance for all joints. The laser kerf makes all parts fit up nicely. (sometimes you can put a 1” peg in a 1” hole).
Glowforge settings: manual cut, speed 150, power 100%
I’ve included the 123D file with all parts and .svg files for each part.
The spindle is a piece of ½” PVC pipe.
The cut-off tool is an old hacksaw blade cut to size and attached with screws.
Each .svg file contains one part. For those parts that require more than one copy just add them in as needed for best use of material.

Note: I designed this for function not form. Some of the parts are not totally symmetrical, so when you fit it together for gluing they only fit one way.

Cheap 1.75mm dual drive extruder using standard parts. It uses 4 drive gears, two of them function as gears, keeping the other two drive gears in sync. The secondary gear is tilted to adjust the pressure on the filament. Make sure the set screws don't interfere during assembly, shorter set screws may be needed on some of the drive gears.

Parts:

  • 1 x Nema 17 Motor
  • 2 x 26 tooth drive gear*
  • 2 x Knurled extruder gears*
  • 2 x MR105 Bearings*
  • 1 x 5 x 30mm Dowel Pin
  • 1 x Bowden Coupler
  • 1 x M3 Heat Set Brass Insert
  • M3 screws (four M3x35mm, one M3x10mm socket cap screws)

More info about how this differs from several other dual drive bowden extruders I've just uploaded on thrinter.com

Printed in Esun Translucent Blue PETG*

*affiliate link

title: Formbot Trex2 Y motor mount and tensioner

description.text:
This replaces the Y tensioner and pulley on the trex2 which is pretty poorly designed by default. You'll need to print this in a strong and temperature resistant material. I used pc-max.

I'd recommend getting a 10mm toothed idler pulley for this, though you may be able to use their bearings (untested).

You can likely reuse the bolt and nut from the current tensioner/idler. The mounts for this are M5, so you'll need some M5 bolts and tnuts.

You'll need a 40mm M5 hex bolt for the idler holder.
These are some of the parts I've used

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072C9831Q/

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B078STSGSX/

author: notnyt

title: Mavic Pro Hand launch and Land

description.text:
I wanted a combination of SAFE Hand or Ground launch system as well as Hand or Ground Landing. This design allows you to either use the landing gear to launch or land or just the Base plate (or grab handle as I named it). I wanted my hands clear of the props but also wanted to be able to land it safely on the ground if I lost signal or decided the ground was clear enough to do so.
The landing gear is the same for both sides, so you only need one file. It is a press fit but it may be safer to glue on.
You made need to file the front Mavic chassis dimple on the base plate as it is a very tight. I used an emery board as I did not feel like doing a complete redesign. Use Cocoon support feature for the landing gear part. I like this design as it keeps me safe and is easy to remove to fit on.

It should work as is; however, I've mounted mine with double sided mounting tape to make it ultra secure. Default orientation should be ready to print.

I also made sure it worked well with these other designs:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1624641

title: Replace Tronxy Melzi Board with Ramps 1.4 - Working 5 Button Display Panel using Marlin 1.1.8

description.text:
Finally, figured out how to get Ramps 1.4 to work with Tronxy 5 button display panel. I combined multiple sources to come up with attached, hope this consolidation of information helps some folks out.

Attached xls file has pinouts & photos that specifically show how to wire the 5 button display panel with ramps 1.4. All that is required in Marlin 1.1.8 is to enable Zonestar approx line 1531.

Wire EXP1 on display panel to Aux-2 on Ramps 1.4, then enable Zonestar option and upload firmware.

Be sure to double check 5v and gnd, you want these right. Also be sure to hook up A1 (display board pin 2) to A12 (Ramps 1.4 D66) or your keypad buttons will not work.

author: randjuk

title: Canon LP-E6N Battery Travel Case with 2 SD card slots

description.text:
This is another riff on the battery travel case I made ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1567301 ), except designed for the Canon LP-E6N battery. I've used that battery case for a couple years now, and it's been flawless. I just upgraded to a Canon 7D Mark II, so it was time to recreate the design for that LP-E6N battery. I reduced the number of SD card slots to 2, because I honestly never used the third one. I have provided a plated version for your convenience.

The top is a press fit, so dimensional accuracy is important. I printed this on a new Creality CR-10, which hasn't been tweaked yet and is producing some awful ringing. I had to sand the corners slightly to make the top fit on without getting stuck. Your mileage may vary. You also shouldn't try to put the top on without batteries in the box, as you run a serious risk of getting the top stuck on. Friction is sometimes not your friend.

description.text:
If you hate seeing people throw their cigarette butts on the ground, recommend them this thing! The portable ash tray can be used to prevent litter and to save half-used butts for later.

The main compartment should be filled with 1-2 cm of sand (to help distinguish any parts that may still be lit), and has a small circular lid that can easily be removed to ash your cigarette into. The main lid can be removed to empty/clean the compartment when needed, and the side compartment can hold partially smoked butts.

description.text: This design I made works as a calendar. The two dice and the three month bars give you the possibility to create every day of the year. Turn them every day to show the current date. Enjoy! It turned out really great on my Ultimaker Original. Hope to see some pictures if you printed one! :) Credits for the font go to http://www.fonts2u.com/display-free-tfb.font

• Make sure the month bars read upwards from the printer bed. (The small left square on your printer bed.)
  • The month bars do not need infill.
  • The date cubes have to be printed with the 1 facing down on the printer bed
  • The date cubes do need infil 10% worked really nice for me.
  • You could use support for the 1, might look better, use low support percentage though. I did not use any support.
    • I added a triangle version as well, it wat requested by radus. Each bar is for one season. If you print this version, please make sure to print the triangle holder as well, otherwise the month will not be visible properly. Good luck!

title: Prusa Mendel Blower Front Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed to mount a 50 mm blower onto the front of my old MakerGear Prusa Mendel (kit), since I wasn't getting the cooling I needed from a 40mm fan. Clamps onto the X-carriage, and you can rotate it up or down so that the blower is pointing at the right position.

NOTE: If you're moving from a fan to a blower, you may need to be very careful with the direction so that the blower doesn't cool the nozzle so much that the filament seizes up inside. (Ask me how I know!) You may also need to reduce the fan power percentage from what you were using with the fan.

Printer:

MakerGear Prusa Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20% hex

Notes:

For best strength for the clamp, it needs to be printed in the orientation shown. I know that means a lot of support material (see my second photo), but it really does work best that way.

Assembly

Secure the clamps with M3 x 20 (or so) screws and nuts. The fan is secured by the two printed pegs at the top and an M4 x 25 screw through the bottom mount.

Design

Designed on OnShape, if you need to modify it for your needs:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/367983d36604e435f827c2ee/w/397bfd09ad460e67f7c04691/e/333bdbea5727fd54f54913a8

It is just the grab handle. Print in red to remind yourself that you are always near spinning props. You may need to sand the fittings as it is very tight. I used an emery board on the rear fitting and it fit snuggly now.

title: Rollercoaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a design for the esso design challenge on my mini factory

rollercoaster that can be build with drinking cans 250ml in combination with 3d printing.

for a working view see the youtube link.

https://youtu.be/6ZWX5sUdo2A

you can start printing with the track en can connectors. Build it all together and than take a 3mm filament for the rail. It will click in to the rail parts.

The rail is connected with parts that can be adjusted in the right direction.

the cars can be joint together by the car to car connector. you can place this by the bearings that are on the top op the track. Leave a little room so they can move with the track when the cars go down the track.

i used bold and nuts of M5, M8 and spacer ring M8. M8 and spacer ring for the bearings (608zz) and for the other connections M5.

Best print and fit is with a ,35 nozzle ,2 layer height.

for the track you can select different lengths. The track part 3 is a flexible part that allows you to twist the track. This part you can also cut it to the right length.

the track parts slides together with al little pressure. It is designed to fit tight. so it is possible you will need to sand it down al little bit for a good connection.

I added some pictures so you can see how everything comes together.

enjoy printing and building your own rollercoaster.
